revision.text:
'''Agapios Salomon Naoum''', BS (1 August 1882 – 1 May 1967) was Archbishop of the [[Melkite Greek Catholic Archeparchy of Tyre]] in Lebanon.
==Life==
Agapios Naoum was ordained on 8 September 1907 Chaplain of the Melkite Basilian of the Most Holy Redeemer. On 3 November 1933, he was appointed as successor to Archbishop [[Maximos IV Sayegh]] to the see of Tyre and on 3 December 1933, by Patriarch [[Cyril IX Moghabghab]] was ordained bishop. On 15 October 1965<ref>[http://www.apostolische-nachfolge.de/asien2.htm]</ref> he resigned his duties as archeparch and with simultaneous appointment as Titular Archbishop of Tarsus of Greek Melkites he became Professor Emeritus until his death on 1 May 1967. Naoum was succeeded by Archbishop [[Georges Haddad]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/bnao.html * http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/tyrz0.htm
{{DEFAULTSORT:Naoum, Agapios}} [[Category:1882 births]] [[Category:1967 deaths]] [[Category:Lebanese people]] [[Category:Melkite Greek Catholic bishops]]

{{Short description|American painter}} {{Infobox artist | name = Agnes Martin | image = File:Agnes_Martin_1954.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Martin in her studio, 1954 | birth_name = Agnes Bernice Martin | birth_date = {{Birth date |1912|03|22}} | birth_place = [[Macklin, Saskatchewan]], Canada | death_date = {{Death date and age|2004|12|16|1912|03|22}} | death_place = [[Taos, New Mexico]], United States | nationality = American | spouse = | field = Painting | training = [[Western Washington University]]
[[Teachers College, Columbia University]]
[[University of New Mexico]] | movement = [[Abstract expressionism]] | works = | patrons = | awards = | elected = | website = }} '''Agnes Bernice Martin''' (March 22, 1912 – December 16, 2004) was a Canadian-born American abstract painter. Her work has been defined as an "essay in discretion on inward-ness and silence". Although she is often considered or referred to as a [[minimalist]], Martin considered herself an [[abstract expressionist]]. She was awarded a [[National Medal of Arts]] from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] in 1998.{{cite news |first=Matt |last=Schudel |title=Influential Abstract Painter Agnes Martin Dies at 92 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn/A9391-2004Dec17 |date=December 18, 2004 |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=November 25, 2011}} ==Personal life== Agnes Bernice Martin was born in 1912 to Scottish Presbyterian farmers in [[Macklin, Saskatchewan]], one of four children.{{Cite news |title=Agnes Martin: the quiet American |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/22341ab2-091f-11e5-b643-00144feabdc0.html |newspaper=Financial Times |date=June 5, 2015 |access-date=October 5, 2015 |issn=0307-1766 |first=Rachel |last=Spence |subscription=yes}}[http://www.moma.org/collection/browse_results.php?criteria=O%3AAD%3AE%3A3787 MoMA | The Collection | Agnes Martin. (American, born Canada. 1912–2004)], ''Moma.org''. Accessed March 28, 2011. From 1919, she grew up in [[Vancouver]].{{cite book|title = Agnes Martin|last1=Morris |first1=Frances |last2=Bell |first2=Tiffany |publisher=Tate Publishing |year=2015 |isbn=978 1 84976 268 7 |location=London}}{{rp|237}} She moved to the [[United States]] in 1931 to help her pregnant sister, Mirabell, in Bellingham, Washington.{{rp|237}} She preferred American higher education and became an American citizen in 1950.[http://www.guggenheimcollection.org/site/artist_bio_103.html Collection Online | Agnes Martin] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060215233601/http://www.guggenheimcollection.org/site/artist_bio_103.html |date=2006-02-15 }}, ''Guggenheimcollection.org''. Accessed March 28, 2011. Martin studied at [[Western Washington University]] College of Education, [[Bellingham, Washington]], prior to receiving her B.A. (1942) from [[Teachers College, Columbia University]].{{cite news |first=Holland |last=Cotter |title=Agnes Martin, Abstract Painter, Dies at 92 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/17/arts/design/17martin.html |date=December 17, 2004 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=November 25, 2011}} In 1947 she attended the Summer Field School of the University of New Mexico in [[Taos, New Mexico]].{{rp|237}} After hearing lectures by the Zen Buddhist scholar [[D. T. Suzuki]] at Columbia, she became interested in Asian thought, not as a religious discipline, but as a code of ethics, a practical how-to for getting through life. A few years following graduation, Martin matriculated at the [[University of New Mexico]], Albuquerque, where she also taught art courses before returning to Columbia University to earn her M.A. (1952).{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Knight |title=Agnes Martin, 92; Abstract Painter Won the Golden Lion |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/dec/17/local/me-martin17 |date=December 17, 2004 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=November 25, 2011}} She moved to New York City in 1957 and lived in a loft in Coenties Slip in lower Manhattan.{{rp|238}} She left New York City in 1967, disappearing from the art world to live alone.{{Cite news |title = Pretty as a picture |url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/740d2868-fa30-11e4-a41c-00144feab7de.html |newspaper=Financial Times |date=May 22, 2015 |access-date=October 5, 2015 |issn = 0307-1766 |first = Charlie |last = Porter |subscription=yes}} After eighteen months on the road, Martin settled in [[Cuba, New Mexico]] (1968-1977), and then [[Galisteo, New Mexico]] (1977-1993).{{rp|240}} She built an adobe home for herself in each location. She lived alone all her adult life. In 1993 she moved to a retirement residence in [[Taos, New Mexico]], where she lived until her death in 2004.{{rp|242}} She was publicly known to have schizophrenia, once opting for electric shock therapy for treatment. Many of her paintings bear positive names such as ''Happy Holiday'' (1999) and ''I Love the Whole World'' (2000). In an interview in 1989, discussing her life and her painting, Agnes Martin said, "Beauty and perfection are the same. They never occur without happiness."{{cite web |url=http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/interviews/oral-history-interview-agnes-martin-13296 |title=Oral history interview with Agnes Martin, 1989 May 15 |publisher=Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution |accessdate=October 6, 2015 }} A pioneer of her time, Agnes Martin never publicly expressed her sexuality, but has been described as a 'closeted homosexual' (sic).{{cite web|last1=Fiske|first1=Courtney|title=Agnes Martin |url=http://www.brooklynrail.org/2012/04/art_books/agnes-martin-fiske-apr2012 |website=www.brooklynrail.org |publisher=The Brooklyn Rail |accessdate=7 March 2015}} The 2018 biography ''Agnes Martin: Pioneer, Painter, Icon'' uncovers several romantic relationships between Martin and other women, including the dealer [[Betty Parsons]].{{Cite book |title=Agnes Martin: pioneer, painter, icon |first=Henry |last=Martin |isbn=978-1-943156-30-6 |edition=First paperback |publisher=Schaffner |location=Tucson, Arizona |oclc=981962171}} She often employed an intersectional feminist lens when she critiqued fellow artists' work. Jaleh Mansoor, an art historian, states that Martin was "too engaged in a feminist relation to practice, perhaps, to objectify and label it as such".{{cite journal |last1=Schiff |first1=Karen L. |title=Agnes Martin, Under New Auspices |journal=Art Journal |date=March 4, 2013 |volume=71 |issue=3 |pages=121–125}} ==Career== Her work is most closely associated with Taos, with some of her early work visibly inspired by the desert environment of New Mexico. She moved to New York City at the invitation of the artist/gallery owner Betty Parsons in 1957 (the women had met prior to 1954). That year, she settled in [[Coenties Slip (Manhattan)|Coenties Slip]] in lower Manhattan, where her friends and neighbors, several of whom were also affiliated with Parsons, included [[Robert Indiana]], [[Ellsworth Kelly]], [[Jack Youngerman]], and [[Lenore Tawney]]. [[Barnett Newman]] actively promoted Martin's work, and helped install Martin's exhibitions at Betty Parsons Gallery beginning in the late 1950s.{{cite web |url=http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?intObjectID=5147496 |author=Agnes Martin |title=Starlight 1963, Lot Notes |publisher=[[Christie's]] |location=New York |work=Post War and Contemporary Art Evening Sale |date=November 12, 2008 |accessdate=March 22, 2014}} Another close friend and mentor was [[Ad Reinhardt]].{{cite news |first=Ann |last=Landi |date=March 13, 2012 |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203753704577253590562995200 |title=Saved From the Artist's Fire |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |accessdate=6 August 2017 |subscription=yes}} In 1961 Martin contributed a brief introduction to a brochure for her friend [[Lenore Tawney]]'s first [[Solo show (art exhibition)|solo exhibition]], the only occasion on which she wrote on the work of a fellow artist.{{cite web |url=http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?intObjectID=5437870 |title=Agnes Martin ''Homage to Greece'' (1959) |publisher=[[Christie's]] |location=New York |work=Post War and Contemporary Art Evening Sale |date=May 11, 2011 |accessdate=October 6, 2015}} In 1967, Martin famously abandoned her life in New York. Cited reasons include the death of her friend Ad Reinhardt the demolition of many buildings on Coenties Slip, and a breakup with the artist [[Chryssa]] whom Martin had dated off and on throughout the 1960s. In her ten years living in New York Martin was frequently hospitalised to control symptoms of schizophrenia which manifested in the artist in a number of ways, including aural hallucinations and states of catatonia: on a number of occasions she received electroconvulsive therapy at Manhattan's [[Bellevue Hospital]]. After Martin left New York, she drove about the western US and Canada, deciding to settle in [[Cuba, New Mexico]] for a few years (1968-1977), then settled in [[Galisteo, New Mexico]] (1977-1993).{{rp|240–242}} In both New Mexico homes, she built adobe brick structures herself. She did not return to art until 1973 and consciously distanced herself from the social life and social events that brought other artists into the public eye. She collaborated with architect Bill Katz in 1974 on a log cabin she would use as her studio.{{cite journal |author=Bagley, Christopher |date=March 2008 |url=http://www.wmagazine.com/artdesign/2008/03/bill_katz |title=Perfect Vision |journal=[[W Magazine]] |accessdate=October 6, 2015}} That same year, she completed a group of new paintings and from 1975 they were exhibited regularly. In 1976 she made her first film, ''[[Gabriel (1976 film)|Gabriel]]'', a 78-minute landscape film which features a little boy going for a walk.{{Cite book|title = Agnes Martin: Her Life and Art|last = Princenthal|first = Nancy|publisher = Thames & Hudson|year = 2015|isbn = 978 0 500 09390 0|location = London|pages = 199}} A second movie, ''Captivity'', was never completed after the artist threw the rough cut into the town dump. According to a filmed interview with her which was released in 2003, she had moved from New York City only when she was told her rented loft/workspace/studio would be no longer available because of the building's imminent demolition. She went on further to state that she could not conceive of working in any other space in New York. When she died at age 92, she was said not to have read a newspaper for the last 50 years. Essays in the book dedicated to the exhibition of her work in New York at The [[Drawing Center]] (traveling to other museums as well) in 2005 – ''3x abstraction'' – analyzed the spiritual dimension in Martin's work.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Ew8pPV-59MC |title=3 X Abstraction: New Methods of Drawing, Hilma Af Klint, Emma Kunz, Agnes Martin |editor1=de Zegher, Catherine |editor2=Telcher, Hendel |year=2005 |work=The Drawing Center |publisher=Yale University Press |isbn=978-0300108262 |quote=Published on the occasion of the exhibition 3 x abstraction: new methods of drawing by Hilma af Klint, Emma Kunz, and Agnes Martin ; Organized by the Drawing Center ; The Drawing Center, New York, NY, March 19-May 21, 2005, Santa Monica Museum of Art, Santa Monica, CA, June 10-August 13, 2005, Irish Museum of Modern Art, Dublin, January 24-March 26, 2006.}} The 2018 biography ''Agnes Martin: Pioneer, Painter, Icon'' was the first book to explore Martin's relationship with women and her early life in substantial detail and was written in collaboration with Martin's family and friends. The Agnes Martin estate is represented by [[Pace Gallery]], New York.{{cite web |url=http://www.pacegallery.com/artists/290/agnes-martin/bio |title=Agnes Martin |publisher=Pace Gallery |location=New York |date=2015 |accessdate=6 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151006234756/http://www.pacegallery.com/artists/290/agnes-martin/bio |archivedate=6 October 2015 |df= }} ==Artistic style== In addition to a couple of self-portraits and a few watercolor landscapes, Martin's early works included biomorphic paintings in subdued colors made when the artist had a grant to work in Taos between 1955 and 1957. However, she did her best to seek out and destroy paintings from the years when she was taking her first steps into abstraction. Martin praised [[Mark Rothko]] for having "reached zero so that nothing could stand in the way of truth". Following his example Martin also pared down to the most reductive elements to encourage a perception of perfection and to emphasize transcendent reality.{{cite web |url=http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?intObjectID=5147467 |title=Agnes Martin, ''Untitled #1'' (1989) |publisher=[[Christie's]] |location=New York |work=Post War and Contemporary Art Evening Sale |date=November 12, 2008 |accessdate=October 6, 2015}} Her signature style was defined by an emphasis upon line, grids, and fields of extremely subtle color. Particularly in her breakthrough years of the early 1960s, she created 6 × 6 foot square canvases that were covered in dense, minute and softly delineated graphite grids.{{cite web |url=http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?intObjectID=4978845 |title=Agnes Martin, ''Loving Love'' (2000) |publisher=[[Christie's]] |location=New York |work=Post War and Contemporary Art Evening Sale |date=November 13, 2007 |accessdate=October 6, 2015}} In the 1966 exhibition ''Systemic Painting'' at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]], Martin's grids were therefore celebrated as examples of [[Minimalist art]] and were hung among works by artists including [[Sol LeWitt]], [[Robert Ryman]], and [[Donald Judd]].{{cite web |url=http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/exhibitions/publications/from-the-archives/items/view/72 |title=Systemic Painting: Catalogue for the Exhibition |author=Alloway, Lawrence |year=1966 |publisher=Guggenheim Museum |accessdate=October 6, 2015 |location=New York}} While minimalist in form, however, these paintings were quite different in spirit from those of her other minimalist counterparts, retaining small flaws and unmistakable traces of the artist's hand; she shied away from [[intellectualism]], favoring the personal and spiritual. Her paintings, statements, and influential writings often reflected an interest in Eastern philosophy, especially [[Taoism|Taoist]]. Because of her work's added spiritual dimension, which became more and more dominant after 1967, she preferred to be classified as an [[abstract expressionism|abstract expressionist]]. Martin worked only in black, white, and brown before moving to New Mexico. The last painting before she abandoned her career, and left New York in 1967, ''Trumpet'', marked a departure in that the single rectangle evolved into an overall grid of rectangles. In this painting the rectangles were drawn in pencil over uneven washes of gray translucent paint.{{cite web |url=http://www.zwirnerandwirth.com/exhibitions/2003/022003Martin/press.html |title=Agnes Martin: Five Decades, February 20 – April 26, 2003 |publisher=[[David Zwirner Gallery|Zwirner & Wirth Gallery]] |location=New York |accessdate=October 6, 2015}} In 1973, she returned to art making, and produced a portfolio of 30 serigraphs, ''On a Clear Day''.{{cite web |url=http://www.gallery.ca/en/see/collections/artist.php?iartistid=3556 |title=Agnes Martin 1912 - 2004 |publisher=National Gallery of Canada |location=Ottawa |accessdate=October 6, 2015}} During her time in Taos, she introduced light pastel washes to her grids, colors that shimmered in the changing light.{{cite web |url=http://www.diacenter.org/exhibitions/introduction/89 |publisher=Dia Art Foundation |title=Exhibition: Agnes Martin long term view |location=New York |accessdate=March 28, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927044855/http://www.diacenter.org/exhibitions/introduction/89 |archivedate=September 27, 2011 |df= }} Later, Martin reduced the scale of her signature 72 × 72 square paintings to 60 × 60 inches{{cite web |url=http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?intObjectID=3918126 |title=Agnes Martin ''Untitled No. 4'' (1994) |publisher=[[Christie's]] |location=New York |work=Post War and Contemporary Art Evening Sale |date=May 14, 2002 |accessdate=October 6, 2015}} and shifted her work to use bands of ethereal color.{{cite web |url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artists/agnes-martin-1583 |title=Agnes Martin 1912–2004: Artist biography |work=Catalogue of the Tate Gallery's Collection of Modern Art other than Works by British Artists |author=Alley, Ronald |year=1981 |page=488 |location=London |accessdate=October 6, 2015}} Another departure was a modification, if not a refinement, of the grid structure, which Martin has used since the late 1950s. In ''Untitled No. 4'' (1994), for example, one viewed the gentle striations of pencil line and primary color washes of diluted acrylic paint blended with gesso. The lines, which encompassed this painting, were not measured by a ruler, but rather intuitively marked by the artist. In the 1990s, symmetry would often give way to varying widths of horizontal bands. ==Exhibitions== Since her first solo exhibition in 1958, Martin's work has been the subject of more than 85 solo shows and two retrospectives including the survey, ''Agnes Martin'', organized by the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]], New York, which later traveled to Jamaica (1992–94) and ''Agnes Martin: Paintings and Drawings 1874–1900'' organized by the [[Stedelijk Museum]], Amsterdam, with subsequent venues in France and Germany (1991–92). In 1998, The [[New Mexico Museum of Art|Museum of Fine Arts]] in Santa Fe, New Mexico mounted Agnes Martin Works on Paper. In 2002, the [[Menil Collection]], Houston, mounted ''Agnes Martin: The Nineties and Beyond''. That same year, the [[Harwood Museum of Art]] at the [[University of New Mexico]], Pandora, organized ''Agnes Martin: Paintings from 2001'', as well as a symposium honoring Martin on the occasion of her 90th birthday. In addition to participating in an international array of group exhibitions such as the [[Venice Biennale]] (1997, 1980, 1976), the [[Whitney Biennial]] (1995, 1977), and [[Documenta]], Kassel, Germany (1972), Martin has been the recipient of multiple honors including the Lifetime Achievement Award on behalf of the Women's Caucus for Art of the [[College Art Association]] (2005); Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] (1992);{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780–2010: Chapter B |url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterB.pdf |publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|accessdate=July 25, 2014}} the Governor's Award for Excellence and Achievement in the Arts given by Governor [[Gary Johnson]], Santa Fe, New Mexico (1998); the [[National Medal of Arts]][http://www.nea.gov/honors/medals/medalists_year.html#98 Lifetime Honors – National Medal of Arts] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721054307/http://www.nea.gov/honors/medals/medalists_year.html |date=2011-07-21 }}, ''nea.gov''. Accessed March 28, 2011. awarded by President [[Bill Clinton]] and the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] (1998); the Distinguished Artist Award for Lifetime Achievement by the [[College Art Association]] (1998); the [[Golden Lion]] for Contribution to Contemporary Art at the [[Venice Biennale]] (1997); the Oskar Kokoschka Prize awarded by the Austrian government (1992); the Alexej von Jawlensky Prize awarded by the city of Wiesbaden, Germany (1991); and election to the [[American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters]], New York (1989).{{cite web|url=http://www.artsandletters.org/academicians2_deceased.php |title=Deceased Members: Agnes Martin |accessdate=March 23, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726004624/http://www.artsandletters.org/academicians2_deceased.php |archivedate=July 26, 2011 }} Exhibitions continue to be mounted since her death in 2004, including Agnes Martin: Closing the Circle, Early and Late Feb 10, 2006 – Mar 04, 2006 at Pace Gallery.{{cite web |url=http://www.pacegallery.com/newyork/exhibitions/11830/agnes-martin-closing-the-circle-early-and-late |title=Agnes Martin: Closing the Circle, Early and Late |publisher=Pace Gallery |date=February 10, 2006 |accessdate=October 6, 2015}} Other exhibitions have been held in New York, Zurich, London, Dublin, Edinburgh, Cambridge (England), Aspen, Albuquerque, New Mexico and in [[Penticton]], British Columbia in Canada.{{cite web |url=http://www.pacegallery.com/artists/290/agnes-martin/documents |title=Agnes Martin: Selected One-Artist Exhibitions |work=Biographical documents |publisher=Pace Gallery |accessdate=October 6, 2015}} In 2015, [[Tate Modern]] ran a retrospective of her life and career from the 1950s until her last work in 2004, which will travel to other museums after the show in London. At the [[University of Michigan Museum of Art]], Martin was featured in the exhibition ''Reductive Minimalism: Women Artists in Dialogue, 1960-2014'' which examined the two generations of [[Minimalism|Minimalist]] art side-by-side, from October 2014 through January 2015. The exhibition included [[Anne Truitt]], [[Mary Corse]], and contemporary artists [[Shirazeh Houshiary]] and [[Tomma Abts]]. She was also featured in ''White on the White: Color, Scene, and Space'' in [[Hiroshima City Museum of Contemporary Art]]. From October 2015 through April 2016, Martin was exhibited in ''Opening the Box: Unpacking Minimalism'' at The George Economou Collection in Athens, Greece alongside [[Dan Flavin]] and [[Donald Judd]]. From 2015 to 2017 she had numerous solo exhibitions, some being at the [[Aspen Art Museum]] in Aspen Colorado, [[Tate Modern]] in London, [[K20 Center|K20,]] [[Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen|Kunstsammlung Nordhein-Westfalen]] in Dusseldorf, [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]] (LACMA) in Los Angeles, [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] in the Upper East Side, at the [[Palace of Governor-General in Kiev|Palace of Governors]], The New Mexico Museum of History in Santa Fe. She is featured in the ongoing exhibition Intuitive Progression at the Fisher Landau Center for Art in Long Island City, New York from February 2017 to August 2017.{{Cite web |url=https://www.mutualart.com/Artist/Agnes-Martin/8E9DC2766A9B654A/Exhibitions |title=Events & Exhibitions of Agnes Martin (Canadian, 1912 - 2004) 15 April–13 August 2017 |last=|first=|date= |publisher=Mutual Art, Agnes Martin Exhibitions |accessdate=3 March 2017}} In 2016, a retrospective exhibition of her works from the 1950's through 2004 was presented at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] in New York.{{Cite web|url=https://www.guggenheim.org/exhibition/agnes-martin|title=Agnes Martin|date=2016-02-02|language=en-US|access-date=August 5, 2016}} In 2016 she was also featured in the ''Dansaekhwa and Minimalism Exhibition'' at Blum & Poe, Los Angeles{{cite news |url=http://artobserved.com/2016/02/los-angeles-dansaekhwa-and-minimalism-at-blum-poe-through-march-12th-2016/ |title=Dansaekhwa and Minimalism at Blum & Poe Through March 12th, 2016 |date=February 26, 2016 |accessdate=April 13, 2017 |newspaper=Art Observed |last=Creahan |first=D. }} and earlier in the year in the show titled ''Aspects of Minimalism: Selections from East End Collections'' at the Guild Hall Museum in East Hampton, New York.{{cite news |url=http://artdaily.com/index.asp?int_sec=11&int_new=89483#.WO9kG6K1vmQ |title=Guild Hall Museum opens "Aspects of Minimalism: Selections from East End Collections" |accessdate=April 13, 2017 |publisher=Art Daily}} She will also be featured in ''Making Space: Women Artists and Postwar Abstraction'' at [[Museum of Modern Art|The Museum of Modern Art]] in Midtown, New York which shines light on women artists who worked post [[World War II]] and before the start of the [[Feminist movement]]. The exhibition is from April 2017 to August 2017 and features [[Lee Krasner]], [[Helen Frankenthaler]], and [[Joan Mitchell]], [[Lygia Clark]], [[Gego]], [[Magdalena Abakanowicz]], [[Louise Bourgeois]], and [[Eva Hesse]]. ==Collections== Martin's work can be found in major public collections in the United States, including the [[New Mexico Museum of Art]], Santa Fe, NM; [[Albright-Knox Art Gallery]], Buffalo, NY; The [[Chinati Foundation]], Marfa, TX; [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]], Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C.; [[Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art]]; [[The Menil Collection]], Houston, TX; [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], New York; [[The Museum of Modern Art]], New York; [[National Gallery of Art]], Washington, D.C.; [[Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art]], Kansas City; [[San Francisco Museum of Modern Art]]; [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]], New York; [[Wadsworth Atheneum]] Museum of Art, Hartford; [[Walker Art Center]], Minneapolis; [[Whitney Museum of American Art]], New York; and [[Des Moines Art Center]], Des Moines, IA, among others. Her work is on "long-term view" and part of the permanent holdings of [[Dia Art Foundation]], Beacon, New York. International holdings of Martin's work include the [[Tate]], London and Magasin 3 Stockholm Konsthall, Stockholm, Sweden.{{cite web |url=https://www.magasin3.com/en/publication/agnes-martin-2/ |title=Exhibition folder: Agnes Martin |publisher=Magasin III: Museum & Foundation for Contemporary Art |location=Stockholm |accessdate=October 6, 2015 }}{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/jun/07/agnes-martin-retrospective-review-tate-modern |title=Agnes Martin review – beauty and steeliness |author=Cooke, Rachel |publisher=The Guardian |date=June 7, 2015 |accessdate=October 6, 2015}} ==Legacy== Martin became an inspiration to younger artists, from [[Eva Hesse]] to [[Ellen Gallagher]].{{cite web |author=Holland Cotter |date=December 17, 2004 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/17/arts/design/17martin.html |title=Agnes Martin, Abstract Painter, Dies at 92 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=March 23, 2014}} In 1994, the [[Harwood Museum of Art]] in Taos, part of the [[University of New Mexico]], announced that it would renovate its Pueblo-revival building and dedicate one wing to Martin's work.Carol Vogel (September 23, 1994), [https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/23/arts/inside-art.html The Agnes Martin Wing] ''The New York Times''. The gallery was designed according to the artist's wishes in order to accommodate Martin's gift of seven large untitled paintings made between 1993 and 1994.{{cite web |url=http://www.harwoodmuseum.org/exhibitions/view/59 |title=Agnes Martin Gallery, The Harwood Museum of Art, University of New Mexico |location=Taos, NM |publisher=HarwoodMuseum.org |accessdate=March 28, 2011}} An Albuquerque architectural firm, Kells & Craig, designed the octagonal gallery with an [[oculus]] installed overhead, and four yellow [[Donald Judd]] benches placed directly under the oculus.{{cite web |url=http://harwoodmuseum.org/about/faqs |title=Can you help me understand the Agnes Martin Gallery? |publisher=Harwood Museum of Art |location=Taos, NM |accessdate=March 23, 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.kellsandcraig.com/Projects_Base.html |title=Harwood Museum |accessdate=March 23, 2014 |work=Kells + Craig Projects}} The gift of the paintings and gallery's design and construction were negotiated and overseen by [[Robert M. Ellis]], the Harwood's director at the time and a close friend of Martin's. Today, the Agnes Martin Gallery attracts visitors from all over the world and has been compared by scholars to the [[Chapelle du Rosaire de Vence]] (Matisse Chapel), Corbusier's [[Chapel of Notre Dame du Haut]] in Ronchamp, and the [[Rothko Chapel]] in Houston. == Films about Martin == * 2000: Thomas Luechinger: ''On a Clear Day – Agnes Martin.''{{cite web |url=http://www.sikart.ch/kuenstlerinnen.aspx?id=4001147 |author=Luechinger, Thomas |language=German |publisher=Swiss Institute for Art Research |date=2001 |title=Video Installation about Agnes Martin |accessdate=January 31, 2016 }} Documentary, 52 Minutes. * 2002: Mary Lance: ''Agnes Martin: With my Back to the World.''{{cite web |url=http://www.newdealfilms.com/documentaries/agnes-martin-with-my-back-to-the-world |publisher=New Deal Films |title=Agnes Martin: With My Back to the World |author=Lance, Mary |isbn=1-878917-10-2 |year=2002 |accessdate=January 31, 2016}} Documentary, 57 Minutes. * 2002/2016 (re-edited): Leon d'Avigdor: ''[[Agnes Martin: Between the Lines]].''{{cite web |url=http://www.leon-davigdor.com/agnes-martin_between_the_lines.html |title=Agnes Martin: Between the Lines |year=2002 |author=d'Avigdor, Leon |isbn=978-3-00-052261-1 | accessdate=January 31, 2016 |quote=Screening: Parts of a roughcut of the movie are screened until March 6, 2016, at Kunstsammlung NRW Duesseldorf (Germany) as part of the accompanying program of the exhibition.}} Documentary, 60 Minutes. ==Art market== In 2007, Martin's ''Loving Love'' (2000) was sold for $2.95 million at [[Christie's]], New York. In 2015, ''Untitled #7'' (1984), a white acrylic painting with geometric pencil lines, sold for $4.2 million at [[Phillips (auctioneers)|Phillips]] in New York.{{cite news |first1=Katya |last1=Kazakina |first2=James |last2=Tarmy |date=May 15, 2015 |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-05-15/art-market-reaches-new-milestone-with-2-7-billion-sales-frenzy |title=Art Market Reaches New Milestone With $2.7 Billion Sales Frenzy |newspaper=Bloomberg Business |accessdate=July 22, 2018}} In 2016, her ''Orange Grove'' sold at auction for $13.7 million, the same year as the Guggenheim held a retrospective of her work.{{cite web |title=The Canadian roots and turbulent life of abstract painter Agnes Martin |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/art-and-architecture/article-the-canadian-roots-and-turbulent-life-of-abstract-painter-agnes-martin/ |website=www.theglobeandmail.com |accessdate=22 July 2018 |date=6 July 2018}} ==In popular culture== Composer [[John Zorn]]'s ''[[Redbird (John Zorn album)|Redbird]]'' (1995) was inspired by and dedicated to Martin.[http://www.tzadik.com/index.php?catalog=7008 Tzadik catalogue] [[Wendy Beckett]], in her book ''American Masterpieces,'' said about Martin: "Agnes Martin often speaks of joy; she sees it as the desired condition of all life. Who would disagree with her?... No-one who has seriously spent time before an Agnes Martin, letting its peace communicate itself, receiving its inexplicable and ineffable happiness, has ever been disappointed. The work awes, not just with its delicacy, but with its vigor, and this power and visual interest is something that has to be experienced."{{Cite book |title = Sister Wendy's American Masterpieces |last=Beckett |first= Wendy |publisher=DK |edition=1st American |year=2000 |isbn=978-0789459589 |location=Mishawaka, Indiana, U.S.A.|page= }} Poet Hugh Behm-Steinberg's poem "Gridding, after some sentences by Agnes Martin" discusses patterns in the natural world, makes a parallel between writing and painting, and ends with a line about the poet's admiration of Martin's work.{{cite journal |last1=Behm-Steinberg |first1=Hugh |year=2008 |title=Three Poems |journal=EOAGH: A Journal of the Arts |volume= |issue=4 |pages= |publisher=Charles Alexander |doi= |url=http://chax.org/eoagh/issuefour/behm-steinberg.html |accessdate=March 23, 2011 }} Her work inspired a [[Google doodle]] on the 102nd anniversary of her birth on March 22, 2014. The doodle takes color cues from Agnes Martin's late work which is marked by soft edges, muted colors and distinctly horizontal bands, turned to six vertical bars, one for each letter of the Google logo.{{cite news |title=Agnes Martin: To celebrate the great painter, Google Doodle offers meditative muted beauty |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/comic-riffs/wp/2014/03/22/agnes-martin-to-celebrate-the-great-painter-google-doodle-offers-meditative-muted-beauty/ |author=Michael Cavna |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=March 22, 2014 |accessdate=March 25, 2014}} In 2018, [[Screaming Females]], a New Jersey-based punk band, released a track titled after the late artist in their album [[All at Once (Screaming Females album)|All at Once]]. == Related Minimalist artists == * [[Anne Truitt]], (1921-2004), American sculptor * [[Carl Andre]] (born 1935), American sculptor * [[Jo Baer]] (born 1929), American artist, associated with minimalist art * [[Larry Bell (artist)|Larry Bell]] (born 1939), American sculptor * [[Ronald Bladen]] (1918–1988), American sculptor * [[Dan Flavin]] (1933–1996), American installation artist, [[fluorescent light]] sculpture * [[Donald Judd]] (1928–1994), American sculptor * [[Sol LeWitt]] (1928-2007), American installation artist * [[Robert Mangold]] (born 1937), American painter * [[John McCracken (artist)|John McCracken]] (1934-2011), American sculptor * [[Robert Morris (artist)|Robert Morris]] (born 1931), American sculptor * [[Robert Ryman]] (born 1930), American painter * [[Fred Sandback]] (1943–2003), American installation artist * [[Tony Smith (sculptor)|Tony Smith]] (1912–1980), pioneer of minimalist sculpture * [[Frank Stella]] (born 1936), American painter/sculptor ==Bibliography== * {{cite book |last=Martin |first=Agnes |title=Writings / Schriften |editor=Dieter Schwarz, Winterthur |location=Ostfildern |publisher=Hatje Cantz Verlag |year=1991 |edition=English and German |isbn=3-89322-326-6}} * {{cite book |last=Martin |first=Agnes |chapter=The Untroubled Mind |title=Theories and Documents of Contemporary Art |editor1=Stiles, Kristine |editor2=Selz, Peter |location=Berkeley |publisher=University of California Press |year=1996 |pages=128–137 |isbn=0-520-20253-8}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Berggruen |first=Olivier |chapter=Agnes Martin - The Lightness of Art |title=The Writing of Art |publisher=Pushkin Press |year=2011 |isbn=978 1 906548 62 9}} * {{cite book |editor=Brandauer, Aline |title=Agnes Martin: Works on Paper |publisher=Lumen Books |year=1999 |isbn=978-0936050249 }} * {{cite news |last=Castle |first=Jack |title=Philosopher, artist, pioneer, recluse |work=Art World News |date=June 2, 2015 |url=http://www.christies.com/features/Agnes-Martin-Philosopher-artist-pioneer-recluse-6176-1.aspx?PID=newsviews_landing_morefeatures2 |accessdate=2015-06-03}} An interview with [[Arne Glimcher]]. * {{cite book |last=Fer |first=Briony |chapter=Drawing Drawing: Agnes Martin's Infinity |title=3x An Abstraction: New Methods of Drawing by Hilma af Klint, Emma Kunz, and Agnes Martin |editor=de Zegher, Catherine |editor2=Teicher, Hendel |location=New Haven |publisher=Yale University Press |year=2005 |isbn=978-0300108262}} **Reprinted in {{cite book |title=Women Artists at the Millennium |editor=Armstrong, Carol |editor2=de Zegher, Catherine |publisher=MIT Press |series=October Books |year=2006 |isbn=978-0262012263}} * {{cite book |last=Glimcher |first=Arne |title=Agnes Martin: Paintings, Writings, Remembrances |series=20th Century Living Masters |publisher=Phaidon Press |year=2012 |isbn=978-0714859965}} * {{cite book |last=Haskell |first=Barbara |title=Agnes Martin |location=New York |publisher=Whitney Museum of American Art |year=1992 |isbn=978-0810968059}} * {{cite book |last=Krauss |first=Rosalind E. |chapter=Agnes Martin: The/Cloud/ |title=Inside the Visible: An Elliptical Traverse of 20th Century Art in, of, and From the Feminine |edition=2nd |editor=de Zegher, Catherine |publisher=MIT Press |year=1996 |isbn=978-0262540810}} * {{cite book |last1=Martin |first1=Henry |title=Agnes Martin: Pioneer, Painter, Icon |publisher=Schaffner Press |isbn=978-1943156306}} * {{cite book |editor-last1=Morris |editor-first1=Frances |editor-last2=Bell |editor-first2=Tiffany |title=Agnes Martin |publisher=Tate Publishing |year=2015|isbn=978-1-84976-268-7 }} * {{cite book |last=Pollock |first=Griselda |chapter=Agnes Dreaming: Dreaming Agnes |title=3x An Abstraction: New Methods of Drawing by Hilma af Klint, Emma Kunz, and Agnes Martin |editor=de Zegher, Catherine |editor2=Teicher, Hendel |location=New Haven |publisher=Yale University Press |year=2005 |isbn=978-0300108262}} * {{cite book |last=Woodman |first=Donald |year=2015 |title=Agnes Martin and Me |publisher=Lyon Artbooks |isbn=978-0996784306}} ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} *[http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artists/agnes-martin-1583/who-agnes-martin Filmed interview of Agnes Martin - TateShots] *[https://www.moma.org/artists/3787 Agnes Martin in the collection of The Museum of Modern Art] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I2Fyzav8MxE&t=4s How to Paint Like Agnes Martin, MoMA] *[http://www.zwirnerandwirth.com/exhibitions/2003/022003Martin/ Zwirner & Wirth: Agnes Martin Five Decades] *[http://artnet.com/artist/641822/agnes-martin.html Agnes Martin on artnet] *{{YouTube|_-JfYjmo5OA|Interview with Agnes Martin (1997)}} by Chuck Smith and Sono Kuwayama *[http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/interviews/oral-history-interview-agnes-martin-13296 Oral history interview with Agnes Martin, 1989 May 15], ''Archives of American Art'' *[http://sam.nmartmuseum.org/people/622/agnes-martin/objects Agnes Martin at New Mexico Museum of Art] Retrieved on 2017 November 5 *[http://www.brainpickings.org/index.php/2013/03/22/agnes-martin-1997-interview/ Iconic Painter Agnes Martin on Art, Solitude, and the Secret of Happiness: Interview by Maria Popova in revision.text:
'''Alexander Vargo''' (Russian: Александр Варго) is an official pseudonym used by group of [[Russia]]n [[horror fiction|horror]] writers whose books are published by [[Eksmo]] publishing house in the Myst (Black Book) series.
==History==
Vargo's first novel, The Cook (Russian: Кулинар), was released in 2003. For several years readers thought that Alexander Vargo was a real author, but soon a rumor appeared that a whole group of writers was standing behind this name. The rumor was proved true in the beginning of 2011 when [[Darker magazine]] released an interview with a few authors of the "Vargo"-team and they confirmed that the real Alexander Vargo never existed and the series was just a publisher's project .{{citation needed|date=February 2012}} The name of the original "Vargo"-writer is [[Sergey Dyomin]] (Russian: Сергей Дёмин). Several of "Vargo's" books were also written by [[Igor Isaichev]] and [[Alexei Sholokhov]].
==Bibliography==
*2003 '''The Cook''' (Кулинар) *2008 '''Asylum''' (Приют) *2008 '''The Something''' (Нечто) *2008 '''Wild Beach''' (Дикий пляж) *2008 '''Cocktail Ice''' (Льдинка) *2008 '''Root of All Evil''' (Корень зла) *2008 '''The Clairvoyant''' (Медиум) *2009 '''The Puppet''' (Кукла) *2009 '''House in a Ravine''' (Дом в овраге) *2009 '''Christmas''' (Кристмас) *2010 '''Midnight''' (Полночь) *2011 '''Species''' (Особь) *2011 '''Makeup Man''' (Гримёр) *2011 '''Unhuman''' (Нечеловек) *2011 '''The Sarcophagus''' (Саркофаг) *2011 '''Wraith Awakes''' (Морок пробуждается) *2012 '''Electrician''' (Электрик)
==External links== * [http://darkermagazine.ru/page/aleksandr-vargo-v-rossii-material-dlja-horrora-lezhit-prakticheski-pod-nogami Alexander Vargo: the revealing interview] <!-- 2015-05-29 not found at ISFDB, LCCN, VIAF, WorldCat -->
{{DEFAULTSORT:Vargo, Alexander}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Russian horror writers]] [[Category:Collective pseudonyms]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Philippine name|Ojales|Curtis-Smith|Heussaff|ph=married}} {{Infobox person | name = Anne Curtis | image = Anne Curtis, 2009 (cropped).jpg | birth_name = Anne Ojales Curtis-Smith | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1985|2|17|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Yarrawonga, Victoria]], Australia | othername = | nationality = [[Filipino Australians|Filipino-Australian]] | education = | occupation = Actress, television host, singer | agent = [[Viva Communications|Viva Artists Agency]]
(1997–present)
[[GMA Network]]
(1997-2003)
[[ABS-CBN]]
(2004–present) | spouse = {{marriage|Erwan Heusaff|2017}} | family = [[Jasmine Curtis-Smith]] (sister)
Thomas James Curtis-Smith (brother)
Carmencita Ojales Curtis-Smith (mother)
James Ernest Curtis-Smith (father) | relatives = [[Solenn Heussaff]] (sister-in-law) | website = {{URL|http://www.anne.ph/}} }} '''Anne Curtis-Smith-Heussaff''' (born February 17, 1985){{cite web|url=http://www.annecurtis.ph/my-story-2 |title=My Story |accessdate=25 February 2014}} is a [[Filipino Australian|Filipino-Australian]] actress, model, television host, VJ and recording artist in the [[Philippines]].{{cite web |url=http://www.celebrityring.info/Anne_Curtis.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071122052155/http://www.celebrityring.info/Anne_Curtis.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 November 2007 |title=Anne Curtis pictures & biography |publisher=celebrityring.info |accessdate=8 October 2013 }} She is currently one of the hosts of the noontime variety show [[It's Showtime (variety show)|It's]] [[It's Showtime (variety show)|Showtime]], which airs on ABS-CBN. Curtis starred in several television series, which include ''[[Hiram (TV series)|Hiram]]'' (2004–2005), ''[[Kampanerang Kuba]]'' (2005), ''[[Maging Sino Ka Man]]'' (2006–2007) ''[[Dyosa]]'' (2008), ''[[The Wedding (TV series)|The Wedding]]'' (2009), ''[[Green Rose (Philippine TV series)|Green Rose]]'' (2011), and ''[[Kailangan Ko'y Ikaw (TV series)|Kailangan Ko'y Ikaw]]'' (2013), and has hosted the noontime show ''[[It's Showtime (variety show)|It's Showtime]]'' (2009–present). In 2014, she portrays the iconic [[Philippine comics|Komiks]] character [[Dyesebel]] in ''[[Dyesebel (2014 TV series)|Mars Ravelo's Dyesebel]]''. She also starred in several films like ''[[No Other Woman]]'' (2011), which grossed Php 278 million at the box office{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/intl/philippines/?yr=2011&wk=44¤cy=local&p=.htm |title=Philippines Box Office November 2–6 |accessdate=27 February 2014}} and her role in the film earned her a [[FAMAS Award for Best Actress]]. Her other box-office hit films include ''[[Babe, I Love You]]'' (2010) and ''[[A Secret Affair]]'' (2012). Her other critically lauded roles were in the films ''[[Baler (film)|Baler]]'' (2008) and ''[[In Your Eyes (2010 film)|In Your Eyes]]'' (2010). Throughout her career, she has received a [[Metro Manila Film Festival|Metro Manila Film Festival Award]], three [[FAMAS Award]] nominations (winning one), three PMPC Star Award for Movies nominations, two [[Luna Awards|Luna Award]] nominations (winning one), and six [[PMPC Star Awards for TV|PMPC Star Award for TV]] nominations (winning two).{{cite web| url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1034352/awards| title=Anne Curtis Awards| accessdate=28 February 2014}} ==Early life== Curtis was born in [[Yarrawonga, Victoria]], Australia, the daughter of Carmen Cita ojales , a Filipina from Bolinao, Pangasinan and James Ernest Curtis-Smith, an Australian lawyer.{{cite web|title=Jasmine Curtis-Smith Biography|url=http://www.pinoystop.com/bio/celebrity-profile/286/jasmine-curtissmith-biography|publisher=''Pinoy Stop''|accessdate=22 December 2014}} Her father is a World War II veteran and married Carmencita Ojales in 1982.{{Cite web|url=https://globalnation.inquirer.net/134825/aussie-war-vet-has-deeper-ties-to-ph-as-annes-jasmines-dad|title=Aussie war vet has deeper ties to PH as Anne’s, Jasmine’s dad|last=Cardinoza|first=Gabriel|website=globalnation.inquirer.net|access-date=2016-12-13}} Her younger sister, [[Jasmine Curtis-Smith|Jasmine]], is also an actress. On their father's side, they had a half-sister named Clare who died in 2007 due to a [[cardiovascular disease]] at four months old.{{cite news|last1=Dumaual|first1=Miguel|title=Anne Curtis talks about sister's death|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/01/12/13/anne-curtis-talks-about-sisters-death|accessdate=22 December 2014|publisher=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]]|work=[[ABS-CBNnews.com]]|date=12 January 2013}} Curtis, being half-[[Filipino people|Filipino]], would visit her mother's relatives in the Philippines with her family. In 1997, 12-year-old Curtis was approached by a talent scout to ask if she would like to get into a children's [[beauty pageant]]. Her father feared that it was a scam, while her mother wanted her to try it. Without her father's knowledge, Curtis then started to go to different talent agencies. and meet her first boyfriend Anthony, By that time, she and her family decided to stay permanently in the Philippines. Curtis could not speak or understand the [[Filipino language]] at the time, and so had to take classes. ==Career== ===1997–2003: Career beginnings=== About a month later, Curtis was asked if she wanted to try acting. She said yes and she auditioned for a part in the movie [[Magic Temple (film series)#Magic Kingdom|Magic Kingdom]]. where she won the role of Princess Dahlia. Afterwards, she signed with [[Viva Films]]. Her first television appearance was in [[GMA 7]]'s ''[[Ikaw Na Sana]].'' She was then cast as Emily in the teen-oriented show, ''[[TGIS]].'' She also starred in the television series ''[[Anna Karenina (Philippine TV series)|Anna Karenina]]''. Curtis starred in minor and supporting roles in the films ''Honey, My Love... So Sweet'', ''Ika-13 Kapitulo'', ''[[Juan & Ted: Wanted]]'' and in the television shows ''[[May Bukas Pa (1999 TV series)|May Bukas Pa]]'', ''[[Beh Bote Nga]]'', and ''[[Idol Ko si Kap]]''. ===2004–2010: Breakthrough=== In 2004, Curtis moved from [[GMA 7]] to [[ABS-CBN]], stating the move "majorly life changing."{{cite web|url= http://www.philstar.com/sunday-life/2013/02/10/906801/anne-curtis-party-girl-best-actress| title=Anne Curtis: From party girl to best actress| publisher=philSTAR.com| first=Bianca| last=Gonzalez |date=10 February 2013 |accessdate=25 February 2014}} She then acted alongside [[Dina Bonnevie]] and [[Kris Aquino]] in ''[[Hiram (TV series)|Hiram]]'', which aired until 2005.{{cite web|url= http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/2013/09/01/1157331/e-news-asia-turns-spotlight-anne-curtis| title=E! News Asia turns the spotlight on Anne Curtis | publisher=philSTAR.com| date=1 September 2013 |accessdate=25 February 2014}} Aside from ''[[Hiram (TV series)|Hiram]]'', Curtis also joined ''[[ASAP (variety show)|ASAP]]'' as a host and as a performer. Curtis' big break came in 2005 when she won the title role in the television series ''[[Kampanerang Kuba]]''. This marked her first collaboration with director [[Wenn V. Deramas]]. Curtis admitted that Deramas was eyeing another actress for the role, but she auditioned anyway. In this project, she got the chance to work with veteran actresses [[Eula Valdez]] and [[Jean Garcia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/275991/anne-curtis-kampanerang-kuba| title=Anne Curtis is Kampanerang Kuba| date=1 May 2005 |accessdate=25 February 2014}} Curtis then hosted the reality show ''[[Qpids]]'' with [[Luis Manzano]],{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/young-star/297023/starlet-express| title=Starlet express| publisher=philSTAR.com| first=Celine| last=Lopez |date=16 September 2005 |accessdate=25 February 2014}} and a segment in ''[[The Buzz (talk show)|The Buzz]]'' called ''Wannabuzz''.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/299271/swamped-work| title=Swamped with work| publisher=philSTAR.com |date=30 September 2005 |accessdate=25 February 2014}} In 2006, Curtis, along with [[Luis Manzano]], hosted ''[[Star Circle Quest|Star Circle Summer Kid Quest]].''{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/cebu-entertainment/339254/ann-curtis-lucky-find-soulmate| title= Ann Curtis lucky to find a soulmate| publisher=philSTAR.com| first=Nathalie| last=Tomada| date=29 May 2006| accessdate=25 February 2014}} That same year, she starred in ''[[All About Love (2006 film)|All About Love]]'', a three-in-one love flick where she co-starred with [[John Lloyd Cruz]], [[Bea Alonzo]], [[Luis Manzano]], [[Angelica Panganiban]] and [[Jason Abalos]]. She then filmed ''[[Wag Kang Lilingon]]'' with [[Kristine Hermosa]].{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/368335/anne-looks-back-%C2%97-never-regrets| title= Anne looks back — but never regrets | publisher=philSTAR.com| first=Jerry| last=Donato| date=22 November 2006| accessdate=25 February 2014}} She portrayed Celine Magsaysay in the drama series ''[[Maging Sino Ka Man]]'' where she received raved reviews for her performance.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/373208/%C2%92tis-season-anne-curtis |title=Tis the season of Anne Curtis| publisher=philSTAR.com |date=4 December 2006 |accessdate=25 February 2014}} and received a nomination for Best Drama Actress at the [[PMPC Star Awards for TV]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/15202/PMPC-bares-nominees-in-the-21st-Star-Awards-for-Television| title= PMPC bares nominees in the 21st Star Awards for Television | publisher=PEP.ph| date=21 October 2007 |accessdate=25 February 2014}} Curtis co-starred with [[Oyo Boy Sotto]] in ''[[Sineserye Presents]]'': ''[[May Minamahal (TV series)|May Minamahal]]'', .{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/3005/anne-oyo-again| title= Anne & Oyo: Again?| publisher=philSTAR.com| first=Maridol| last=maridol rañoa-bismark| date=30 May 2007| accessdate=25 February 2014}} She reprised her role of Celine Magsaysay in the second instalment of ''[[Maging Sino Ka Man]]'', entitled ''[[Maging Sino Ka Man: Ang Pagbabalik]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/1374/abs-cbns-maging-sino-ka-man-returns-with-book-2| title= ABS-CBN's "Maging Sino Ka Man" Returns with Book 2| publisher=PEP.ph| first=Paul| last=Mata| date=6 December 2007| accessdate=25 February 2014}} She reunited with [[Wenn V. Deramas]] on their second collaboration, ''[[Ang Cute Ng Ina Mo]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/469/ang-cute-ng-ina-mo-opens-in-theaters-on-april-7-| title= "Ang Cute ng Ina Mo" opens in theaters on April 7 | publisher=PEP.ph| first=Jocelyn| last=Dimaculangan| date=4 April 2007| accessdate=25 February 2014}} In 2008, Curtis starred in ''[[When Love Begins]]'', a romantic drama film where she was paired with [[Aga Muhlach]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/1811/Aga-Muhlach-and-Anne-Curtis-make-love-team-in-When-Love-Begins| title= Aga Muhlach and Anne Curtis make love team in "When Love Begins" | publisher=PEP.ph| first=Jocelyn| last=Dimaculangan| date=11 April 2008| accessdate=26 February 2014}} In July 2008, Curtis was announced to play the lead role in ''[[Baler (film)|Baler]]'', alongside [[Jericho Rosales]]. The film was an official entry to [[2008 Metro Manila Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/18194/anne-curtis-and-jericho-rosales-to-star-in-the-period-movie-baler| title= Anne Curtis and Jericho Rosales to star in the period movie "Baler" | publisher=PEP.ph| first=Dino| last=Erece| date=6 July 2008| accessdate=26 February 2014}} Her performance in the film was critically lauded, leading to a [[Metro Manila Film Festival|Metro Manila Film Festival Award for Best Actress]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/20347/baler-wins-10-awards-including-best-picture-in-the-34th-mmff-awards-night| title="Baler" wins 10 awards, including Best Picture in the 34th MMFF Awards Night| publisher=PEP.ph| first=Jocelyn| last=Dimaculangan| date=28 December 2008| accessdate=25 February 2014}} This marked Curtis' first acting award.{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/20353/anne-curtis-overwhelmed-by-mmff-best-actress-trophy| title= Anne Curtis overwhelmed by MMFF Best Actress trophy| publisher=PEP.ph| first=Rose| last=Garcia| date=28 December 2008| accessdate=25 February 2014}} She also received a [[FAMAS Award for Best Actress]] nomination,{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/4831/57th-famas-awards-finalists-revealed| title= 57th FAMAS Awards finalists revealed | publisher=PEP.ph| date=5 October 2009| accessdate=26 February 2014}} a PMPC Star Award for Movies for Movie Actress of the Year nomination,{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/21290/baler-leads-with-13-nominations-in-25th-star-awards-for-movies| title= "Baler" leads with 13 nominations in 25th Star Awards for Movies | publisher=PEP.ph| first=William| last=Reyes| date=26 March 2009| accessdate=25 February 2014}} a Gawad PASADO Award for Pinakapasadong Aktress nomination,{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/3795/Gawad-PASADO-2008-nominees-unveiled| title= Gawad PASADO 2008 nominees unveiled| publisher=PEP.ph| first=Alex| last=Datu| date=27 April 2009| accessdate=25 February 2014}} and a [[Luna Awards|Luna Award for Best Actress]] nomination. Also in 2008, Curtis topbilled the television series ''[[Dyosa]]''. She played four different characters in the said series.{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/18097/anne-curtis-nervous-about-her-starring-role-in-dyosa |title=Anne Curtis nervous about her starring role in "Dyosa" |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Rose |last=Garcia |date=29 June 2008 |accessdate=26 February 2014}} Because of her role in this series, she was dubbed as the "Dyosa" of Philippine Showbiz.{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/18626/anne-curtis-dubbed-as-the-kapamilya-and-philippine-showbiz39s-dyosa |title=Anne Curtis dubbed as the Kapamilya and Philippine showbiz's "Dyosa" |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Julie |last=Bonifacio |date=6 August 2008 |accessdate=26 February 2014}} She became one of the main hosts of the morning variety show, ''[[Showtime (Philippines)|Showtime]]'' in 2009 which included [[Vhong Navarro]], [[Kim Atienza]] and [[Vice Ganda]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/23625/anne-curtis-hosts-new-abs-cbn-daily-program-showtime/1/1 |title=Anne Curtis hosts new ABS-CBN daily program Showtime |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Mell |last=Navarro |date=22 October 2009 |accessdate=26 February 2014}} Also in 2009, she starred in the television series, ''[[The Wedding (TV series)|The Wedding]]'', with [[Zanjoe Marudo]] and [[Derek Ramsay]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/4172/anne-curtis-makes-a-lovely-bride-on-the-wedding |title=Anne Curtis makes a lovely bride on The Wedding |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Nerisa |last=Almo |date=28 June 2009 |accessdate=26 February 2014}} In 2010, she starred in the film ''[[Babe, I Love You]]''. The movie marked her first big-screen team-up with [[Sam Milby]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/movies/5703/Anne-Curtis-and-Sam-Milby-will-shoot-a-love-scene-for-%3Cem%3EBabe-I-Love-You%3C-em%3E |title=Anne Curtis and Sam Milby will shoot a love scene for Babe I Love You |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Nerisa |last=Almo |date=10 March 2010 |accessdate=26 February 2014}} Her second film for 2010 was ''[[In Your Eyes (2010 film)|In Your Eyes]]'' alongside [[Claudine Barretto]] and [[Richard Gutierrez]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/6638/director-mac-alejandre-talks-about-his-latest-movie-in-your-eyes |title=Director Mac Alejandre talks about his latest movie in Your Eyes |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Mark |last=Ching |date=18 August 2010 |accessdate=26 February 2014}} Her role in this film earned her a [[Luna Awards|Luna Award for Best Supporting Actress]]{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/30142/dolphy-and-lorna-tolentino-win-top-acting-honors-at-the-29th-luna-awards-emir-named-best-picture |title=Dolphy and Lorna Tolentino win top acting honors at the 29th Luna Awards; Emir named Best Picture |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Jojo |last=Gabinete |date=11 November 2011 |accessdate=26 February 2014}} and a Movie Actress of the Year nomination at the PMPC Star Awards for Movies.{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/29240/Sa-Yo-Lamang-and-Sigwa-lead-nominations-at-the-27th-Star-Awards-for-Movies |title=Sa 'Yo Lamang and Sigwa lead nominations at the 27th Star Awards for Movies |publisher=PEP.ph |first=William |last=Reyes |date=28 April 2011 |accessdate=26 February 2014}} ===2011–present: Career resurgence=== In 2011, she starred in the Philippine adaptation of the [[Green Rose|Korean series]], ''[[Green Rose (Philippine TV series)|Green Rose]]''. where she starred again with [[Jericho Rosales]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/tv/7625/pinoy-version-of-green-rose-will-start-airing-on-valentine39s-day/1 |title=Pinoy version of Green Rose will start airing on Valentine's Day |publisher=PEP.ph |date=27 February 2012 |accessdate=7 May 2012}} She also topbilled the film ''[[Who's That Girl (2011 film)|Who's That Girl?]]'', which served as her reunion movie with [[Luis Manzano]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/7532/anne-curtis-and-luis-manzano39s-characters-have-a-mix-up-in-who39s-that-girl |title=Anne Curtis and Luis Manzano's characters have a mix-up in Who's That Girl? |publisher=PEP.ph |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=27 February 2014}} Although a confessed non-singer,{{cite web| url=http://www.pep.ph/news/33032/anne-curtis-reiterates-i39m-not-a-singer-i39m-a-performer| title= Anne Curtis reiterates: "I'm not a singer, I'm a performer." |first=Rommel |last=Llanes |date=17 February 2012 |accessdate=27 February 2014}} Curtis launched her debut album, ''[[Annebisyosa]]'', under [[Viva Records (Philippines)|Viva Records]], on 25 September 2011. She asked for her bosses to release her album, as it is one of her dreams.{{cite web |url=http://www.pep.ph/peparazzi/videos/2706/function.include |title=Anne Curtis screams and cries at her album launching |publisher=PEP.ph |date=24 September 2011 |accessdate=8 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130820163118/http://www.pep.ph/peparazzi/videos/2706/function.include |archivedate=20 August 2013 |df=dmy-all }} She described her album as "super fun" and "not serious." She also stated that people should listen at their own risk.{{cite web |url=http://ph.news.yahoo.com/anne-curtis-album-listen-own-risk-032627280.html |title=Anne Curtis on new album: Listen at your own risk – Yahoo! |publisher=Ph.news.yahoo.com |date=22 September 2011 |accessdate=21 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120720105944/http://ph.news.yahoo.com/anne-curtis-album-listen-own-risk-032627280.html |archivedate=20 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} In October 2011, the album reached the gold status, as it sold 10,000 copies. Curtis cried while receiving the gold record award.{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/9137/anne-curtis-cries-upon-receiving-gold-record-award-for-debut-album-annebisyosa |title=Anne Curtis cries upon receiving Gold Record Award for debut album AnneBisyosa |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Allan |last=Sancon |date=17 October 2011 |accessdate=8 May 2012}} The album reached the Platinum status in December 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/mobile/guide/music/9476/anne-curtis-receives-platinum-record-award-for-album-will-hold-concert-at-the-big-dome-on-january-28-2012/7 |title=Anne Curtis receives Platinum Record Award for album; will hold concert at the Big Dome on January 28, 2012 |publisher=PEP.ph |date=11 December 2011 |accessdate=8 May 2012}} On 28 September 2011, her film ''[[No Other Woman]]'', which also starred [[Derek Ramsay]] and [[Cristine Reyes]], was released. It grossed Php 100 million in five days.{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/9039/no-other-woman-grosses-p100-million-in-5-days-according-to-star-cinema |title= No Other Woman grosses P100 million in 5 days, according to Star Cinema |date=3 October 2011 |accessdate=27 February 2014}} The film became the [[List of highest-grossing films in the Philippines|highest-grossing film in the Philippines]],{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/9107/no-other-woman-grosses-p210-million-overtakes-box-office-gross-of-you-changed-my-life-|title= No Other Woman grosses P210 million; overtakes box-office gross of You Changed My Life |date=12 October 2011 |accessdate=27 February 2014}} until it was beaten by ''[[The Unkabogable Praybeyt Benjamin]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/9315/praybeyt-benjamin-grosses-p320-million-in-20-days |title= Praybeyt Benjamin grosses P320 million in 20 days |date=15 November 2011 |accessdate=27 February 2014}} Her performance in the film lead her and co-star [[Cristine Reyes]] to be recognised as the Box Office Queens at the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Foundation's Box-Office Entertainment Awards.{{cite web|url=http://pep.ph/news/33760/vice-ganda-named-phenomenal-box-office-star-derek-ramsay-is-box-office-king-while-anne-curtis-and-cristine-reyes-share-box-office-queen-title/1/2 |title=Vice Ganda named Phenomenal Box-Office Star; Derek Ramsay is Box-Office King while Anne Curtis and Cristine Reyes share Box-Office Queen title |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Nora |last=Calderon |date=15 April 2012 |accessdate=8 May 2012}} She also won as the Pinakapasadong Aktres at the Gawad Pasado Awards{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/33757/in-the-name-of-love-and-sayaw-ng-dalawang-kaliwang-paa-lead-winners-of-pasado-awards |title=In the Name of Love and Sayaw ng Dalawang Kaliwang Paa lead winners of PASADO Awards |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Rodel |last=Fernando |date=15 April 2012 |accessdate=7 May 2012}} and received a [[FAMAS Award for Best Actress]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/35802/anne-curtis-and-governor-er-ejercito-win-top-acting-honors-at-60th-famas-awards |title=In the Name of Love and Sayaw ng Dalawang Kaliwang Paa lead winners of PASADO Awards |publisher=PEP.ph |first=William |last=Reyes |date=26 September 2012 |accessdate=27 February 2014}} At PMPC Star Awards for Movies, she was nominated as Movie Actress of the Year.{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/9958/28th-star-awards-for-movies-winners-will-be-honored-this-wednesday-march-14 |title=28th Star Awards for Movies winners will be honored this Wednesday, March 14 |publisher=PEP.ph |first=William |last=Reyes |date=12 March 2012 |accessdate=8 May 2012}} On 28 January 2012, Curtis staged her first solo concert entitled ''Annebisyosa: No Other Concert World Tour'' at the [[Smart Araneta Coliseum]]. The concert was also in celebration of her 15th year in show business.{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/32285/anne-curtis-on-her-forthcoming-araneta-concert-hindi-ako-papayag-na-walang-birit |title=Anne Curtis on her forthcoming Araneta concert: "Hindi ako papayag na walang birit!" |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Rose |last=Garcia |date=15 December 2011 |accessdate=8 May 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/32782/anne-curtis-on-her-39first-and-last39-major-solo-concert-dreams-do-really-come-true/1/2 |title=Anne Curtis on her 'first and last' major solo concert: "Dreams really do come true." |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Erwin |last=Santiago |date=30 January 2012 |accessdate=8 May 2012}} [[Vhong Navarro]], [[Luis Manzano]], [[Vice Ganda]],{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/32782/anne-curtis-on-her-39first-and-last39-major-solo-concert-dreams-do-really-come-true/1/3 |title=Anne Curtis on her 'first and last' major solo concert: "Dreams do really come true." |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Erwin |last=Santiago |date=30 January 2012 |accessdate=8 May 2012}} [[Rico Blanco]], [[Ira Cruz]],{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/32782/anne-curtis-on-her-39first-and-last39-major-solo-concert-dreams-do-really-come-true/1/4 |title=Anne Curtis on her 'first and last' major solo concert: "Dreams do really come true." |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Erwin |last=Santiago |date=30 January 2012 |accessdate=8 May 2012}} [[Sam Milby]], [[Derek Ramsay]], [[Cristine Reyes]]{{cite web|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/32782/anne-curtis-on-her-39first-and-last39-major-solo-concert-dreams-do-really-come-true/1/5 |title=Anne Curtis on her 'first and last' major solo concert: "Dreams really do come true." |publisher=PEP.ph |first=Erwin |last=Santiago |date=30 January 2012 |accessdate=8 May 2012}} Afterwards, several provincial concerts were held. She also performed internationally in cities such as Hong Kong and California.{{cite web| url=http://www.pep.ph/news/36522/anne-curtis-successfully-brings-annebisyosa-concert-to-hong-kong| title= Anne Curtis successfully brings Annebisyosa concert to Hong Kong |first=Arniel |last=Serato |date=21 November 2012 |accessdate=27 February 2014}}{{cite web| url=http://www.pep.ph/news/38754/anne-curtis-ready-to-invade-california-for-annebisyosa-world-tour| title= Anne Curtis ready to invade California for Annebisyosa world tour |first=Rose|last=Garcia |date=21 May 2013 |accessdate=27 February 2014}} Also in 2012, Curtis' show ''[[It's Showtime (variety show)|Showtime]]'' replaced ''[[Happy Yipee Yehey!]]'' in the noontime slot.{{cite web| url=http://www.pep.ph/news/32789/it39s-showtime-replaces-defunct-happy-yipee-yehey-in-noontime-slot-of-abs-cbn| title= It's Showtime replaces defunct Happy Yipee Yehey! in noontime slot of ABS-CBN |first=Nerisa| last=Almo |date=30 January 2012 |accessdate=27 February 2014}} She also starred in the movie, ''[[A Secret Affair]]'', which earned her third [[FAMAS Award for Best Actress]] nomination.{{cite web| url=https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000232/2013?ref_=nmawd_awd_1| title=FAMAS Awards |accessdate=27 February 2014}} In 2013, Curtis, along with [[Kris Aquino]] and [[Robin Padilla]], led the drama series, ''[[Kailangan Ko'y Ikaw (TV series)|Kailangan Ko'y Ikaw]]''.{{cite web| url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/guide/9748/kris-aquino-robin-padilla-and-anne-curtis-topbill-abs-cbn39s-upcoming-series-kailangan-ko39y-ikaw |first=Jocelyn |last=Dimaculangan |title= Kris Aquino, Robin Padilla and Anne Curtis topbill ABS-CBN's upcoming series, Kailangan Ko'y Ikaw| date=3 February 2012| accessdate=27 February 2014}} Curtis' projects in 2014 included her playing the title role in [[ABS-CBN|ABS-CBN's]] adaptation of [[Mars Ravelo|Mars Ravelo's]] ''[[Dyesebel (2014 TV series)|Dyesebel]]'',{{cite web| url=http://www.pep.ph/news/41873/anne-curtis-is-the-new-dyesebel-faces-the-press-for-the-first-time-after-slapping-incident| first=Bernie| last=Franco | date=10 January 2014| title= Anne Curtis is the new Dyesebel; faces the press for the first time after slapping incident |accessdate=24 February 2014}} comedy film ''The Gifted'' and her second studio album The Forbidden. She had her second solo concert titled 'The Forbidden Concert Annekapal' in May at the [[Smart Araneta Coliseum]]. In 2015, the 'Kuyakoy' moves of Curtis started to become viral online then eventually called as the ‘Kuyakoy Queen’.{{cite web| url=http://trendhalo.com/2015/07/26/watch-kuyakoy-moves-of-anne-curtis/| title=Watch "Kuyakoy" moves of Anne Curtis| date=26 July 2015| accessdate=26 July 2015| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304103153/http://trendhalo.com/2015/07/26/watch-kuyakoy-moves-of-anne-curtis/| archivedate=4 March 2016| df=dmy-all}} In 2016, she became the host of I Love OPM, alongside with Erik Nicolas, a singing competition which involves foreign people. She also guested in FPJ's Ang Probinsyano with Christopher De Leon ==Philanthropy== In March 2015, Curtis became a celebrity advocate for [[UNICEF Philippines]], having been a supporter of the organization since 2009. As an advocate, she visited parts of [[Leyte]] that were devastated by [[Typhoon Haiyan|Typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda)]] in 2013 to meet with children and families affected by the typhoon and observe recovery operations.{{cite news|title=Anne Curtis is new UNICEF celebrity advocate|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/03/05/15/anne-curtis-new-unicef-celebrity-advocate|accessdate=4 February 2016|work=[[ABS-CBNnews.com]]|publisher=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]]|date=5 March 2015}}{{cite news|title=Anne Curtis is newest UNICEF advocate|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/anne-curtis-is-newest-unicef-advocate/169337/|accessdate=4 February 2016|work=[[The Manila Times]]|date=14 March 2015}} In October 2015, Curtis launched a [[marathon]] called the "Heroes for Children Run" to benefit UNICEF's "1,000 Days of Life" campaign.{{cite web|title=Life Peg: Anne Curtis, the It Girl Who's Making A Difference in More Ways than One|url=http://lifestyle.abs-cbn.com/articles/1195/life-peg-anne-curtis-the-it-girl-whos-making-a-difference-in-more-ways-than-one/|publisher=[[ABS-CBN]]|accessdate=21 March 2016|date=9 March 2016}} In February 2016, Curtis announced that she had written a [[Children's literature|children's book]] entitled ''Anita, The Duckling Diva'' in collaboration with UNICEF Philippines.{{cite news|title=LOOK: Anne Curtis is now a book author|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/02/04/16/look-anne-curtis-is-now-a-book-author|accessdate=4 February 2016|work=[[ABS-CBNnews.com]]|publisher=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]]|date=4 February 2016}} ==Personal life== In December 2016, Curtis became engaged to her longtime boyfriend, restaurateur and food blogger Erwan Heussaff, who is the brother of actress, TV host, and model [[Solenn Heussaff]].{{cite news|last1=Dabu|first1=Bianca Rose|title=Anne Curtis engaged to Erwan Heussaff|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/592870/showbiz/anne-curtis-engaged-to-erwan-heussaff|accessdate=23 December 2016|work=[[GMA News Online]]|date=18 December 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Cruz|first1=Marinel|title=She said Yes! Anne Curtis engaged to Erwan Heussaff|url=https://entertainment.inquirer.net/210016/said-yes-anne-curtis-engaged-erwan-heussaff|accessdate=23 December 2016|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=20 December 2016}} On 12 November 2017, Curtis and Heussaff got married in [[Queenstown, New Zealand]].{{cite news|title=Anne Curtis and Erwan Heussaff finally tie the knot in New Zealand|url=http://push.abs-cbn.com/2017/11/12/fresh-scoops/anne-curtis-and-erwan-heussaff-finally-tie-the-kno-171285|accessdate=12 November 2017|publisher=[[ABS-CBN Digital Media]]|date=12 November 2017}} ==Makeup Line== In September 2017, Anne Curtis launched her makeup line in the Philippines.http://www.ruthdelacruz.com/2017/09/anne-curtis-makeup-line-blk-uncomplicated-beauty.html ==Filmography== ===Television=== {| class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible" style="font-size:95%" |+ |- | '''Year''' | '''Title''' | '''Role''' |- | 2016 || ''[[Ang Probinsyano]]'' | Katrina "Trina" Trinidad || Guest Role |- | 2014 || ''[[Dyesebel (2014 TV series)|Mars Ravelo's Dyesebel]]'' || Dyesebel ||Lead Role |- | 2013 || ''[[Kailangan Ko'y Ikaw (TV series)|Kailangan Ko'y Ikaw]]'' || Ruth Manrique || Main cast |- | 2011 || ''[[Green Rose (Philippine TV series)|Green Rose]]'' || Angela Tuazon ||Lead Role |- | 2009 || ''[[The Wedding (TV series)|The Wedding]]'' ||Candice de Menes || Lead Role |- | 2008-2009 || ''[[Dyosa]]'' || Dyosa Tierra (a Centaur) / Dyosa Agua (a Mermaid) / Dyosa Cielo (a Harpy) || Lead Role |- | 2007-2008 || ''[[Maging Sino Ka Man: Ang Pagbabalik]]'' || Celine Magsaysay-Berenguer || Main cast |- | 2007 || ''[[May Minamahal (TV series)|SineSerye Presents: May Minamahal]]'' || Monica Fernandez-Tagle || Lead Role |- | 2006-2007 || ''[[Maging Sino Ka Man]]'' || Celine Magsaysay || Main cast |- | 2005 || ''[[Kampanerang Kuba (2005 TV series)|Pablo S. Gomez's Kampanerang Kuba]]'' || Fatima "Imang" De Vera / Bernadette || Lead Role |- | 2004-2005 || ''[[Hiram (TV series)|Hiram]] || Stephanie Borromeo || Main cast |- | 2003 || ''[[Ang Iibigin Ay Ikaw Pa Rin]]'' || rowspan="2" | Rosanna Luarca |- | 2002-2003 || ''[[Ang Iibigin Ay Ikaw]]'' |- | 1999-2003 || ''[[Beh Bote Nga]]'' || Genie Fer |- | 1997-1999 || ''[[T.G.I.S.|T.G.I.S.
