revision.comment: Rm "alma mater" in favour of "education" in Infobox person. See [[Template talk:Infobox person]]
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Juliana Huxtable | honorific_suffix = | image = [[File:Juliana Huxtable.jpg|250px|DJing at Secret Project Robot]] | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = <!--only use if different from name--> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1987|12|29}} | birth_place = [[College Station–Bryan metropolitan area|Bryan-College Station, Texas]], U.S. | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = | education = [[Bard College]] | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | movement = | spouse = | awards = <!-- {{awd|award|year|title|role|name}} (optional) --> | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | module = }} '''Juliana Huxtable''' (born December 29, 1987)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.out.com/entertainment/popnography/2014/01/09/juliana-huxtables-birthday-party-house-ladosha#slide-0|title=Juliana Huxtable's Birthday Party with House of Ladosha|date=January 9, 2014|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en}}</ref> is an American artist, writer, [[Performance|performer]], DJ, and co-founder of the New York-based nightlife project Shock Value. Huxtable has exhibited and performed at a number of venues including [[Reena Spaulings|Reena Spaulings Fine Art]], Project Native Informant, [[Artists Space]], the [[New Museum]], the [[Museum of Modern Art]], Portland Institute of Contemporary Arts, and [[Institute of Contemporary Arts]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://sfaq.us/2016/03/juliana-huxtable-in-conversation-with-jarrett-earnest/|title=Juliana Huxtable: In Conversation With Jarrett Earnest|work=SFAQ / NYAQ / LXAQ|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> Huxtable's multidisciplinary art practice explores a number of projects, such as the internet, the body, history, and text, often through a process she calls "conditioning."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.artforum.com/words/id=68284|title=Juliana Huxtable talks about conspiracy and her show at Reena Spaulings|last=Fialho|first=As told to Alex|work=artforum.com|access-date=2018-01-02|language=en-US}}</ref> Huxtable is a published author of two books and a member of the New York City-based collective [[House of Ladosha]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/juliana-huxtable-964106|title=Juliana Huxtable is Helping Art Regain Its Stride {{!}} artnet News|date=May 19, 2017|work=artnet News|access-date=2018-01-02|language=en-US}}</ref> She currently lives and works in New York City.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.maskmagazine.com/the-street-issue/work/juliana-huxtable|title=Juliana Huxtable|work=Mask Magazine|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en}}</ref>
== Early life and education == Huxtable was born in [[Houston]], Texas and raised in [[College Station–Bryan metropolitan area|Bryan-College Station, Texas]].<ref>{{Citation|last=School of the Art Institute of Chicago (SAIC)|title=Juliana Huxtable – October 11, 2016|date=July 18, 2017|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eG5soJNJa4k&t=1554s|accessdate=2018-01-02}}</ref> She has described her hometown as a typical "conservative [[Bible Belt]] town in Texas."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/juliana-huxtable-new-museum-triennial|title=Meet Juliana Huxtable: Star of the New Museum Triennial|work=Vogue|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en}}</ref> Huxtable's mother, Kassandra, raised Huxtable and her two siblings alone after Huxtable's parents divorced.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/exmjkp/artist-juliana-huxtables-journey-from-scene-queen-to-trans-art-star-456|title=Artist Juliana Huxtable's Bold, Defiant Vision|date=March 25, 2015|work=Vice|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en-us}}</ref>
Huxtable was born [[intersex]] and began her [[Transitioning (transgender)|transition]] after college. She notes that struggles with gender conformity and sex identity started earlier in life.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/exmjkp/artist-juliana-huxtables-journey-from-scene-queen-to-trans-art-star-456|title=Artist Juliana Huxtable's Bold, Defiant Vision|date=March 25, 2015|work=Vice|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en-us}}</ref>
Huxtable moved to New York to attend [[Bard College]] and graduated in 2010. Huxtable has spoken about the desire to be a painter while growing up and enrolled in several painting classes during college. She abandoned the medium after professors criticized her for her "obsession with" formal technique and identity.<ref>{{Citation|last=School of the Art Institute of Chicago (SAIC)|title=Juliana Huxtable – October 11, 2016|date=July 18, 2017|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eG5soJNJa4k|accessdate=2017-11-06}}</ref> In an interview with artist [[Lorraine O'Grady]], Huxtable mentions studying literature and gender studies.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.moca.org/stream/post/introducing-lorraine-ogrady-and-juliana-huxtable-part-1|title=Introducing: Lorraine O’Grady and Juliana Huxtable, Part 1|work=The Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles|access-date=2017-11-05}}</ref>
==Emerging in New York== Huxtable moved to New York to work as a legal assistant for the [[ACLU]]'s Racial Justice Program after college.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.maskmagazine.com/the-street-issue/work/juliana-huxtable|title=Juliana Huxtable|work=Mask Magazine|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en}}</ref> While at the ACLU, Huxtable amassed a significant following on Tumblr, posting long stream-of-consciousness poems and self-portraits that experimented with fashion and [[Nuwaubian Nation|Nuwaubian]] imagery.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.maskmagazine.com/the-street-issue/work/juliana-huxtable|title=Juliana Huxtable|work=Mask Magazine|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en}}</ref>
After leaving her position at the [[American Civil Liberties Union|ACLU]], Huxtable began DJing.
In 2013, Huxtable participated in the [[House of Ladosha]]'s show ''Whole House Eats'' at [[Superchief Gallery]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/culture/house-of-ladosha-the-whole-house-eats|title=House of Ladosha is C-Word Bound|work=Interview Magazine}}</ref> During her time as a DJ, Huxtable regularly integrated her poetry into [[DJ mixes]]. Huxtable's poetry was featured in the song "Blood Oranges" from [[Le1f]]'s mixtape [[Tree House (Le1f mixtape)|Tree House]] as well as the runway soundtrack for the [[Hood by Air]] Fall/Winter fashion show "10,000 Screaming Faggots" by Total Freedom.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://artforum.com/inprint/issue=201410&id=49111|title=Wu Tsang|author=Wu Tsang|work=artforum.com}}</ref>
Huxtable's interest in fashion led her to model for a number of fashion houses and campaigns. In 2014, she was featured on the fifth anniversary cover of ''C☆NDY'' magazine along with 13 other transgender women – [[Janet Mock]], [[Carmen Carrera]], [[Geena Rocero]], [[Isis King]], [[Gisele Alicea]], [[Leyna Ramous]], [[Dina Marie]], [[Nina Poon]], [[Yasmine Petty]], [[Niki M'nray]], [[Pêche Di]], [[Carmen Xtravaganza]] and [[Laverne Cox]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newnownext.com/laverne-cox-carmen-carrera-on-candy-magazine-cover/12/2014/|title=Laverne Cox, Carmen Carrera, Among 14 Trans Stars On "Candy" Magazine Cover|work=NewNowNext}}</ref> Huxtable has modeled for [[DKNY]], [[Eckhaus Latta]], [[Chromat]], and French fashion house [[Kenzo (brand)|Kenzo]].
In August 2014, Huxtable performed in the video for the [[Hercules and Love Affair]] song "My Offence." The video features excerpts of conversations with figures from New York City's queer nightlife scene such as [[Miss Honey Dijon|Honey Dijon]] and [[Contessa Stuto]]. The band's primary member, Andrew Butler, described the song and its video as an examination of his "relationship to taboo words and the use of 'cunt' amongst NYC's gay community to relay flattery, empowerment and strength".<ref>{{cite web |title=Andy Butler of Hercules And Love Affair Discusses 'My Offence' |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/16/hercules-and-love-affair_n_5679099.html |last=Michelson |first=Noah |date=August 16, 2014 |publisher=The Huffington Post}}</ref>
== Work == === New Museum Triennial and Performa 15 Biennial ===
In early 2015, Huxtable was selected to present work in the 2015 [[New Museum]] Triennial ''Surround Audience,'' curated by [[Lauren Cornell]] and artist [[Ryan Trecartin]]. Huxtable included two text-based works and two self-portraits, each an inkjet print from the series ''Universal Crop Tops For All The Self-Canonized Saints of Becoming.'' These works, along with a sculpture by fellow Triennial artist [[Frank Benson (artist born 1976)|Frank Benson]] that depicted a life-sized Huxtable rendered in iridescent colors, were prominent works in the show.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/02/24/frank-benson-new-museum-triennial/|title=At the 2015 New Museum Triennial, A High-Tech Take on Nude Sculpture|last=McGarry|first=Kevin|website=T Magazine|access-date=2016-02-27}}</ref> Writer Mark Guiducci dubbed Huxtable the "Star of the New Museum Triennial".<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.vogue.com/11894022/juliana-huxtable-new-museum-triennial/|title=Meet Juliana Huxtable: Star of the New Museum Triennial|last=Guiducci|first=Mark|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-13}}</ref>
Huxtable premiered on season two of [[Ovation (U.S. TV channel)|Ovation TV's]] web-based talk show, ''[[Touching the Art]]'', hosted by fellow 2015 Triennial artist [[Casey Jane Ellison]]. Artist [[K8 Hardy]] and New Museum curator Shelley Fox Aarons were also guests in the same episode.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uL82jzwHBNQ|title=Touching the Art – Season 2 – Episode 1 – Biennials & Triennials – Ovation|date=February 19, 2015|work=YouTube}}</ref>
Later that year, Huxtable was selected to showcase a new performance piece in the Performa 15 Biennial. The hour-long performance titled, ''There Are Certain Facts That Cannot Be Disputed,'' was presented at the [[Museum of Modern Art]]. It included poetry, audio and voice over, video elements, and live-music with fellow collaborators and explored the complicated relationship between the ephemeral nature of digital information and the drive for historical documentation on the internet. As described by the festival's organizers, Huxtable's performance considered "cyberspace as a twilight zone of precariousness and preservation, traversing closed servers, bounced URLs, and Google cache as human and digital characters".<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://15.performa-arts.org/events/there-are-certain-facts-that-cannot-be-disputed | title = Juliana Huxtable, There Are Certain Facts That Cannot Be Disputed – Performa 15 | website = Performa 15 | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>
=== ''Shock Value'', House of Ladosha, and other projects === Huxtable is a founder and DJ for ''Shock Value,'' a weekly New York City-based nightlife collective run by women artists, DJs, writers, and fashion icons.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dazeddigital.com/artsandculture/article/20742/1/petra-collins-selects-juliana-huxtable|title=Petra Collins selects Juliana Huxtable|last=Dazed|date=July 8, 2014|work=Dazed|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en}}</ref>
Huxtable is a member of the New York City-based collective [[House of Ladosha]]. Members include Cunty Crawford Ladosha (Adam Radakovich), Neon Christina Ladosha ([[Christopher Udemezue]]), Paws Off Ladosha (Riley Hooker), Magatha Ladosha (Michael Magnan), La Fem Ladosha (Antonio Blair), and YSL Ladosha (Yan Sze Li).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thehouseofladosha.com/|title=The House of Ladosha: THIS IS UR BRAIN|last=O'Moore|first=Madeline|website=thehouseofladosha.com|access-date=2017-11-05}}</ref> In January 2016, House of Ladosha showcased various art projects in ''This Is Your Brain''. In 2017, the collective was selected to participate in the group exhibition ''Trigger: Gender as a Weapon and a Tool'' at the [[New Museum]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newmuseum.org/exhibitions/view/trigger-gender-as-a-tool-and-as-a-weapon|title=Trigger: Gender as a Tool and a Weapon|website=www.newmuseum.org|language=en|access-date=2017-11-05}}</ref> They were also featured in Issue 7 of the magazine ''Gayletter''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gayletter.com/trigger-gender-as-a-tool-and-a-weapon/|title=TRIGGER: GENDER AS A TOOL AND A WEAPON|date=September 29, 2017|work=GAYLETTER|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref>
Huxtable currently sits on the editorial board for Topical Cream, a New York-based platform that supports a community of artists, writers, designers, and technologists through digital publishing and public programming initiatives. Topical Cream was founded in 2013 and its board members include Lyndsy Welgos, Ara Anjargolian, Whitney Mallett, Juliana Huxtable, and [[Aria Dean]].
In 2016, Huxtable was a Visiting Artists Program lecturer at the [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago]].
Huxtable has participated in multiple panels and lectures, including ''Basquiat and Contemporary Queer Art'' hosted by the [[Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture]], ''Transgender in the Mainstream'' hosted by [[Art Basel Miami Beach]], and ''Open Score: Generation You'' presented by the [[New Museum]] and [[Rhizome (organization)|Rhizome]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Art Basel|title=Salon {{!}} Transgender in the Mainstream|date=December 21, 2015|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zsHXmS1jJYE|accessdate=2016-09-13}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Schomburg Center|title=Talks at the Schomburg: Basquiat and Contemporary Queer Art|date=February 8, 2016|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Ov_Kl-rCw0|accessdate=2016-09-13}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Citation|last=New Museum|title=Open Score 2016: Intro + Panel 1: Generation You, presented by New Museum and Rhizome|date=February 22, 2016|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KZ5Ks16ff_o|accessdate=2017-11-05}}</ref>
Later that year, Huxtable headlined the opening night performance of the [[Portland Institute for Contemporary Art]]'s Time-Based Art Festival in Portland, Oregon.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://pica.org/event/juliana-huxtable/|title=Juliana Huxtable – PICA|work=PICA|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Solo exhibitions === Huxtable's first solo exhibition, ''A Split During Laughter at the Rally'', opened at ''[[Reena Spaulings]]'' in New York City in May 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.reenaspaulings.com/JH.htm|title=Reena Spaulings Fine Art|website=www.reenaspaulings.com|access-date=2017-11-05}}</ref> The exhibition featured several posters with DIY-inspired magnets, a video piece featuring members from [[House of Ladosha]], and a flow chart.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/juliana-huxtable-964106|title=Juliana Huxtable is Helping Art Regain Its Stride {{!}} artnet News|date=May 19, 2017|work=artnet News|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> The show explored "the aesthetics of [[conspiracy]] and American paranoia" through various modes of resistance, alienation, and irony. Huxtable notes that the posters in the exhibition were formally inspired by American artist [[Emory Douglas]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.artforum.com/words/id=68284|title=Juliana Huxtable talks about conspiracy and her show at Reena Spaulings|last=Fialho|first=As told to Alex|work=artforum.com|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref>
Huxtable's second solo exhibition, ''Juliana Huxtable'', opened at ''Project Native Informant'' in London, England in October 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://projectnativeinformant.com/exhibition/juliana-huxtable/|title=Project Native Informant – Juliana Huxtable|website=projectnativeinformant.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-05}}</ref> The exhibition featured three photographs of a black subject with various (often conflicting) tattoos, four sculptural paintings made of military-style clothing, and ten pamphlet-sized posters recounting, "a brawl between Antifa leftist skinheads and Nazi skinheads outside of a Fred Perry sample sale in Paris".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ssense.com/en-us/editorial/culture/juliana-huxtables-conspiracy-logic|title=Juliana Huxtable's Conspiracy Logic|last=SSENSE|date=October 27, 2017|work=ssense|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en-us}}</ref> The show continues Huxtable's exploration into conspiracy theories and paranoia, subcultures, and identity but on a more humorous note. Fashion also plays a major role throughout Huxtable's practice as this show highlights. Huxtable has referenced Jose Esteban-Muñoz's "Disidentification" as a major inspiration.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thewhitereview.org/reviews/juliana-huxtable-pni/|title=Juliana Huxtable, PNI – The White ReviewThe White Review|website=www.thewhitereview.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-05}}</ref>
=== Books === Huxtable is the author of two books and has contributed to numerous chapbooks and artist's writing anthologies.
Her first book, ''Mucus in My Pineal Gland,'' was published in 2017 by Capricious. The book is a collection of previously performed poems, like ''UNTITLED (FOR STEWART)'' and ''THERE ARE CERTAIN FACTS THAT CANNOT BE DISPUTED,'' as well as a number of new poems.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/juliana-huxtable-964106|title=Juliana Huxtable is Helping Art Regain Its Stride {{!}} artnet News|date=May 19, 2017|work=artnet News|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> The book is written in her typical all-caps style and blue font.
Huxtable's second book, ''Life'', was co-written with artist [[Hannah Black]]. The novel is a work of science-fiction and is written in both English and German. It was released in 2017 by König.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.aqnb.com/2017/03/16/hannah-black-juliana-huxtables-life-book-release-and-opening-at-mumok-mar-16/|title=Averting the end of the world: Hannah Black + Juliana Huxtable’s LIFE book release + opening at Mumok, Mar 16|date=March 16, 2017|work=atractivoquenobello|access-date=2017-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Themes == '''Style'''
Huxtable's practice is interdisciplinary by nature and thus explores a range of topics. Earlier works explore ideas of identity, the body, and text, with influences from [[Afrofuturism]] and science fiction. Huxtable's more recent works explore [[language]], [[Conspiracy theory|conspiracy theories]], fashion ([[Baroque]] costumes, [[military surplus]], [[punk subculture|punk]] aesthetics, etc.), and various [[counterculture]]s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ssense.com/en-us/editorial/culture/juliana-huxtables-conspiracy-logic|title=Juliana Huxtable's Conspiracy Logic|last=SSENSE|date=October 27, 2017|work=ssense|access-date=2017-11-06|language=en-us}}</ref> Huxtable's visual practice includes, "examining and remixing enduring imagery that, in her observations, retain 'symbolic power.'"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/juliana-huxtable-964106|title=Juliana Huxtable is Helping Art Regain Its Stride {{!}} artnet News|date=May 19, 2017|work=artnet News|access-date=2017-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
Steven Zultanski writes of Huxtable's ''Mucus in My Pineal Gland'', "...doesn't idealize genrelessness, it moves between genres, unmooring moments of personal experience and speculative thought from literary conventions in order to situate them in the world outside of the text, while reflecting on and enjoying those conventions."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://4columns.org/zultanski-steven/mucus-in-my-pineal-gland|title=Mucus in My Pineal Gland|last=Zultanski|first=Steven|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref> Huxtable often, "references her use of digital spaces, including [[Tumblr]]," [[chat room]]s, [[social media]], online sexual [[subculture]]s, [[Encarta]], and [[Afripedia Project|Afripedia]] as well as [[childhood]], fashion, [[consumer culture]], and the [[African diaspora]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.out.com/art-books/2017/5/31/all-caps-imagination-juliana-huxtable|title=The All Caps Imagination of Juliana Huxtable|date=May 31, 2017|access-date=2017-11-06|language=en}}</ref>
'''Influences'''
Huxtable has noted a range of influences including writers [[Octavia E. Butler|Octavia Butler]] and [[Samuel R. Delany]], theorists [[Luce Irigaray]] and [[José Esteban Muñoz|Jose Esteban-Muñoz]], and the visual aesthetics of video director [[Hype Williams (director)|Hype Williams,]] bands [[TLC (group)|TLC]] and [[Blaque]], and singer [[Aaliyah]].<ref>{{Citation|last=School of the Art Institute of Chicago (SAIC)|title=Juliana Huxtable – October 11, 2016|date=July 18, 2017|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eG5soJNJa4k|accessdate=2017-11-06}}</ref> [[Nuwaubian Nation|Nuwaubian culture]] has often been a major source of inspiration for her as well. Huxtable's ''Mucus in My Pineal Gland'' is dedicated to "[[Herculine Barbin|Herculine]], [[Jorge Luis Borges|Borges]], [[House of Ladosha|LaDosha]], and Pickaninny Punks."

==Bibliography== * ''Life: a novel'', co-written with [[Hannah Black]] (König, 2017). [[OCLC]] [https://www.worldcat.org/title/hannah-black-juliana-huxtable-life-a-novel/oclc/988257749&referer=brief_results 988257749] * ''Mucus in My Pineal Gland'' (Capricious and Wonder, 2017). [[OCLC]] [https://www.worldcat.org/title/mucus-in-my-pineal-gland/oclc/987796847&referer=brief_results 987796847] * ''Social medium: artists writing 2000–2015'' (Paper Monument, 2016). [[OCLC]] [https://www.worldcat.org/title/social-medium-artists-writing-2000-2015/oclc/957598488&referer=brief_results 957598488] * ''Future Perfect'', edited by Andrew Durbin (BGSQD, 2014). [[OCLC]] [https://www.worldcat.org/title/future-perfect/oclc/876708570&referer=brief_results 876708570] * ''The Animated Reader: Poetry of 'Surround Audience''' (New York: [[New Museum]]: in association with [[McNally Jackson]], 2015). [[OCLC]] [https://www.worldcat.org/title/animated-reader-poetry-of-surround-audience/oclc/949731062&referer=brief_results 949731062] * ''[[New Art Dealers Alliance]] Contemporary Poetry Zine,'' curated by Sam Gordon (Brooklyn: Sam Gordon, 2013) [[OCLC]] [https://www.worldcat.org/title/contemporary-poetry-zine/oclc/892560607&referer=brief_results 892560607]

{{no footnotes|date=January 2013}} The '''Kalmykian Cavalry Corps''' ('''{{lang-de|Kalmücken-Kavallerie-Korps}}''') was a unit of about 5,000 Kalmyk volunteers who chose to join the [[German Army (Wehrmacht)|German Army]] in 1942 rather than remain in [[Kalmykia]] as German forces retreated before the [[Red Army]].<ref name="Pohl1999">{{cite book|author=J. Otto Pohl|title=Ethnic Cleansing in the USSR, 1937-1949|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b9VoAAAAMAAJ|year=1999|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=978-0-313-30921-2|pages=61–65}}</ref> In 1943, Stalin subsequently declared the Kalmyk population as a whole to be German collaborators and [[Kalmyk deportations of 1943|had them deported]] to [[Siberia]] suffering great loss of life.
==Origins== When [[Erich von Manstein]] led the [[German 16th Infantry Division|16th Motorized Infantry Division]] into Kalmykia in early 1942 he already had some Kalmyk advisors from a committee drawn together by [[Goebbels]] for propaganda purposes. These were supplemented by other Kalmyks who had settled in [[Belgrade]] following their flight with [[White Movement|White Russian]] emigres after the Russian [[October Revolution]].
==Organization== Kalmyk Kavallerie Korps acted within German [[Wehrmacht]] as an independent allied force with all leadership positions taken by [[Kalmyk people|Kalmyks]]. Most of the officers were Kalmyks themselves, with previous Soviet military experience. A few Germans that were present within the corps performed only auxiliary and administrative functions.
Unlike most other national "volunteer" divisions, the Kalmykian Cavalry Corps incorporated genuine volunteers willing to fight together with Germans. The other national divisions relied upon recruits from [[prisoner-of-war camp|POW camps]].<ref name="Pohl1997">{{cite book|author=J. Otto Pohl|title=The Stalinist Penal System: A Statistical History of Soviet Repression and Terror, 1930-1953|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B5vaAAAAMAAJ|year=1997|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-0336-3|page=96}}</ref> More Kalmyks fought in the Kalmykian Cavalry Corps than in comparable units of the Soviet army.<ref name="Müller2014"/>
==Military actions== The Kalmykian Cavalry Corps fought with the Wehrmacht behind the lines,<ref name="Munoz2001">{{cite book|author=Antonio J. Munoz|title=The East Came West: Muslim, Hindu and Buddhist Volunteers in the German Armed Forces, 1941-1945|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wHPzAAAAMAAJ|year=2001|publisher=Axis Europa Books|isbn=978-1-891227-39-4|pages=158–213}}</ref> especially around the [[Azov Sea]]. At the end of 1944, the surviving Kalmyk cavalry troops, together with their families, retreated with the German army.<ref name="Müller2014">{{cite book|author=Rolf-Dieter Müller|title=The Unknown Eastern Front: The Wehrmacht and Hitler's Foreign Soldiers|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bSvaAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA248|date=28 February 2014|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-1-78076-890-8|pages=248–249}}</ref> About 2,000 went to [[Silesia]], [[Poland]] and 1,500 to [[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]], where they were reorganized to fight against the [[Partisan (military)|partisans]].
==End of the war== After the war, nearly all of the surviving Kalmyk soldiers along with the Kalmyk families that accompanied them were forcibly repatriated to the Soviet Union.
The Kalmykian people were internally deported for 13 years as a punishment for collaborating with Germans.<ref name="Gouchinova2013">{{cite book|author=Elza-Bair Mataskovna Gouchinova|title=The Kalmyks|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lVNz1wjFVxsC&pg=PA221|date=11 January 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-77887-3|page=221}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Tiger Legion]] * [[Turkic, Caucasian, Cossack, and Crimean collaborationism with the Axis powers]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Klaus Krippendorff''' (born 1932) is the [[Gregory Bateson]] professor for [[Cybernetics]], [[Language]], and [[Culture]] at the [[University of Pennsylvania]]'s [[Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania|Annenberg School for Communication]].
== Overview == Klaus Krippendorff was born in 1932 in [[Frankfurt am Main]] in [[Weimar Germany|Germany]]. In 1954, he graduated with an engineering degree from the State Engineering School [[Hannover]]. In 1961, he graduated as diplom-designer from the [[Ulm School of Design]] (Hochschule für Gestaltung Ulm), Germany. And in 1967, he received his [[Ph.D.]] in [[communication]]s from the pioneering Institute for Communication Research at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]].
Krippendorff started to work as an engineer and during the last year of his graduate study of [[design]] he was a Research Assistant at the Institute for Visual Perception at the [[Ulm School of Design]]. In 1961 he came to the United States with a two-year Ford International Fellowship, first to [[Princeton University]] but completing his second graduate education at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]]. In 1964, he joined the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania.<ref name = "KK CV">[http://www.asc.upenn.edu/usr/krippendorff/page2vita.htm CV Klaus Krippendorff], retrieved September 2007.</ref>
He is or was a member of the editorial boards of multiple academic journals, such as ''Communication and Information Science'', ''Communication Research'', ''Constructivist Foundations'', ''[[Cybernetics and Human Knowing|Cybernetics & Human Knowing]]'', ''International Journal of Cultural Studies'' and the ''Journal of Communication''.<ref name = "KK CV"/>
In 1971, he was awarded an honorary MA from the University of Pennsylvania. In the same year, he received an award for "On Generating Data in Communication Research" as the most outstanding contribution to ''The Journal of Communication,'' published in 1970. In 1979, he became a Fellow of the Netherlands Institute for Advanced Study in the Humanities and Social Sciences. He was elected fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) in 1982, fellow of the International Communication Association (ICA) in 1985, and fellow of the Japanese Society for Science and Design Studies in 1998.
In 1998, graduate students named him as the teacher of the best doctoral course taken at the University of Pennsylvania. In 2000, he became the Gregory Bateson professor for Cybernetics, Language, and Culture at the Annenberg School for Communication. In 2001 he was awarded the Norbert Wiener Medal in Cybernetics in gold by the [[American Society for Cybernetics]]. Also in 2001, he received the ICA Fellows Book Award for his influential text ''Content Analysis, An Introduction to Its Methodology''. In 2004, he received the Norbert Wiener/Hermann Schmidt Prize from the German Society for Cybernetics and German Society for Pedagogy and Information, at the University of Vienna.<ref name = "KK CV"/>
In 2012, the [[Linnaeus University]] in [[Kalmar]]/[[Växjö]], Sweden, awarded him the degree of Doctor of Philosophy ''honoris causa.''
== Selected publications == Krippendorff has published widely on cybernetics and systems theory, methodology in the social sciences, human communication, conversation, and discourse.<ref>[http://www.asc.upenn.edu/usr/krippendorff/page3pub.htm Klaus Krippendorff's Publications]</ref> Among his major works are the following: * 1967, ''An Examination of Content Analysis: A Proposal for a Framework and an Information Calculus for Message Analytic Situations'', Ph.D. Dissertation, Urbana: University of Illinois, 400 pp. * 1970, "Bivariate agreement coefficients for reliability of data", in E. F. Borgatta: ''Sociological Methodology''. San Francisco: Jossey-Bass, 139–150. * 1980, ''Content Analysis; An Introduction to its Methodology'', Beverly Hills, CA: Sage, 188 pp. (Translated into Italian, Japanese, Spanish, and Hungarian) * 1986, ''[http://pespmc1.vub.ac.be/ASC/INDEXASC.html A Dictionary of Cybernetics]'', Norfolk, VA: The American Society for Cybernetics. * 1986, ''Information Theory: Structural Models for Qualitative Data'', Beverly Hills, CA: Sage Publications, 96 pp. * 1989, Product Semantics. With R. Butter (Eds.) ''Design issues, 5''. * 1994, ''Design: A Discourse on Meaning; A Work Book'', Philadelphia PA: University of the Arts. * {{cite web|year=1997|title=Design in the Age of Information, A Report to the National Science Foundation (NSF)|url=http://repository.upenn.edu|page=184}} * 2006, ''[[The Semantic Turn|The Semantic Turn; A New Foundation for Design]]'', New York: Taylor & Francis CRC, 349 pp. (Translated into Japanese) * 2009, ''The Content analysis Reader''. With M. A. Bock (Eds.). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage, 481 pp. * 2009, ''On Communicating; Otherness, Meaning, and Information''. F. Bermejo (Ed.). New York: Routledge, 372 pp. * 2012, ''Content Analysis; An Introduction to its Methodology, 3rd Edition'', Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage, 441 pp.
== See also == * [[Krippendorff's alpha]] * [[Content analysis]] * [[Satisficing]] * [[Social entropy]] * ''[[The Semantic Turn]]''
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.asc.upenn.edu/usr/krippendorff/ Klaus Krippendorff's] Homepage at asc.upenn.edu * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070224044659/http://spmc.open.ac.uk/2003july15-17-spmc-ukss-ouss-21cen-visions.htm Systems practice for managing complexity], International conference 15–17 July 2003, St Anne's College, Oxford.
{{Authority control}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Linda Lingle | image = Linda Lingle in March 2010.jpg | office3 = [[Chief operating officer|Chief Operating Officer]] of [[Illinois]] | governor3 = [[Bruce Rauner]] | term_start3 = January 22, 2015 | term_end3 = July 1, 2016 | predecessor3 = Andrew Ross | successor3 = Trey Childress | order1 = 6th [[Governor of Hawaii]] | lieutenant1 = [[Duke Aiona]] | term_start1 = December 2, 2002 | term_end1 = December 6, 2010 | predecessor1 = [[Ben Cayetano]] | successor1 = [[Neil Abercrombie]] | office2 = 3rd [[Mayor of Maui]] | term_start2 = January 2, 1991 | term_end2 = January 2, 1999 | predecessor2 = [[Hannibal Tavares]] | successor2 = [[James Apana|Kimo Apana]] | birth_name = Linda Cutter | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|6|4}} | birth_place = [[St. Louis]], Missouri, U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | spouse = Charles Lingle {{small|(1972–1975)}}
William Crockett {{small|(1986–1997)}} | education = [[California State University, Northridge]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}} | signature = Linda Lingle signature.svg }} '''Linda Lingle''' (''née'' '''Cutter'''; June 4, 1953) is an American politician, who was the [[List of Governors of Hawaii|sixth governor of Hawaii]] from 2002 until 2010. She was the first [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] governor of Hawaii since 1962. Lingle was also the first [[List of female state governors in the United States|female governor]] of Hawaii and its first Jewish governor. Prior to serving as governor, Lingle served as [[Maui County, Hawaii|Maui County]] mayor, council member, and chair of the [[Hawaii Republican Party]]. During the [[2004 Republican National Convention]] in New York City, Lingle served as chair of the convention during the absence of permanent chair [[Dennis Hastert]] from the convention floor. She was the 2012 [[United States Senate election in Hawaii, 2012|Republican nominee for the United States Senate]], vying unsuccessfully for an open seat vacated by retiring U.S. Senator [[Daniel Akaka]].{{cite news| last=Blake | first= Aaron | title=Chris Cillizza's The Fix: Former governor Linda Lingle to run for Senate in Hawaii | date=October 11, 2011 | newspaper=Washington Post | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/post/former-governor-linda-lingle-to-run-for-senate-in-hawaii/2011/10/11/gIQARlVYcL_blog.html | accessdate=October 18, 2011}}{{cite news| last=DePledge | first=Derrick | title=Lingle joins U.S. Senate race | date=October 11, 2011 | newspaper=Honolulu Star-Advertiser | url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/news/breaking/131499778.html | accessdate=October 18, 2011}} In January 2015, Lingle was appointed as a senior adviser to Illinois Governor [[Bruce Rauner]].{{cite news |url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2015/01/22/rauner-imports-former-hawaii-governor-to-be-top-aide/ |title=Rauner Imports Former Hawaii Governor To Be Top Aide |publisher=CBS Chicago |date=January 22, 2015 |accessdate=January 23, 2015 }} She also serves on the Governors’ Council of the [[Bipartisan Policy Center]] in Washington, D.C. ==Early life, education, and early career== Lingle was born '''Linda Cutter''' to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family{{cite encyclopedia |url=http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/lingle-linda |encyclopedia=Jewish Women: A Comprehensive Historical Encyclopedia |publisher=Jewish Women's Archive |title=Linda Lingle |first=Robert D. |last=Johnston |date=March 1, 2009 |accessdate=June 23, 2015 }} in [[St. Louis, Missouri]] in 1953, the daughter of Mildred and Richard Cutter.{{cite news |url=http://www.midweek.com/coverstory/coverstory010505.html |title=Governor Linda Lingle |newspaper=MidWeek |first=Dan |last=Boylan |date=January 5, 2005 |accessdate=June 23, 2015 }} Lingle moved with her parents to [[Southern California]] when she was 12. She graduated from [[Birmingham High School]] in [[Lake Balboa, California]] (at that time, part of [[Van Nuys]]), then received her bachelor's degree in journalism ''cum laude'' from [[California State University, Northridge]], in 1975. Soon after that, she followed her father to Hawaii, working first in [[Honolulu]] as a public information officer for the [[Teamsters]] and Hotel Workers Union. Later, she moved to [[Molokai]], where she started the ''Molokai Free Press'', a community newspaper.{{cite web |url=http://www.womenspeecharchive.org/women/profile/index.cfm?ProfileID=29&printfriendly=1 |title=Women's Political Communication Archive – Linda Lingle |publisher=Iowa State University Carrie Chapman Catt Center |accessdate=January 10, 2012}} ==County politics== In 1980, Lingle was elected to the [[Maui County]] Council, where she served five two-year terms. Lingle served three of those terms representing Molokai and two terms as an at-large member. Upon the 1990 retirement of [[Hannibal Tavares]] as [[Mayor of Maui|mayor of Maui County]], Lingle decided to challenge former Maui mayor and Hawai'i State Speaker of the House of Representatives [[Elmer Cravalho]] for the seat. Despite polls showing Lingle trailing far behind her [[Democratic Party of Hawaii|Democratic]] opponent, Lingle proved victorious. The ''[[Honolulu Advertiser]]'' and ''[[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]]'' newspapers declared the election one of the biggest upsets in Hawai'i political history. She became the youngest person elected to the office of Maui County Mayor, at the age of 37, as well as the first woman. She was sworn into office as Mayor of Maui on January 2, 1991.{{cite news |title=Other Hawai'i mayors who died in office |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2008/Jun/23/br/hawaii80623070.html |work=[[Honolulu Advertiser]] |date=June 23, 2008 |accessdate=January 10, 2012 |quote=The late Hannibal Tavares won the mayor's seat in a special election in October 1979 to complete Cravalho's term. He became Maui's longest serving mayor, serving until Jan. 2, 1991.}} In 1994, Lingle easily won re-election over her Democratic opponent, Maui County councilman [[Goro Hokama]].{{cite news|first=Gary T. |last=Kubota|title=Maui honors councilman's legacy; A service celebrates Goro Hokama's work in politics and labor |url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/2004/05/29/news/story7.html |work=[[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]] |publisher= |date=2004-05-29 |accessdate=2013-08-26}} Under Lingle's leadership, Maui County implemented performance-based budgeting.{{cite journal |url=http://www.mauimagazine.net/Maui-Magazine/May-June-2008/10-Most-Intriguing-People/index.php?cparticle=6&siarticle=5 |magazine=Maui Magazine |date=May–June 2008 |title=10 Most Intriguing People |last=Sten |first=Michael |accessdate=January 10, 2012 |quote=Her achievements on Maui, where she gained high marks for performance-based budgeting and stimulating job growth, helped propel her to higher office – as Hawai‘i’s first female governor.}} Its successful passage and execution earned for Lingle the ''Distinguished Budget Presentation Award'' from the [[Government Finance Officers Association]] for four years.{{cite web |url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/biography/linglelinda.html |title=Linda Lingle |publisher=Jewish Virtual Library / The American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise |accessdate=January 10, 2012 |quote=Thanks to her leadership, Maui County received the "Government Finance Officers Association Distinguished Budget Presentation Award" for four consecutive years....}} Mayor Lingle was also credited for attracting tourism and job growth to Maui County during a period when the state tourism industry was struggling.{{cite news |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/special/election2002/2002/Oct/27/ln/ln03a.html |title=The Lingle Record: Taxes, spending, growth advanced on her watch |newspaper=The Honolulu Advertiser |date=October 27, 2002 |first=Kevin |last=Dayton |accessdate=January 10, 2012 |quote=Lingle points out that Maui County led the state in job creation during her time as mayor, with the average monthly wage and salary job count increasing by more than 15 percent from 1990 to 1998. Statewide, the job count increased by only two-tenth of 1 percent during the same years. The job growth in Maui was led by hotels, which increased their employment by more than 19 percent, as well as in retailing and government.}} ==1998 gubernatorial campaign== {{Main|Hawaii gubernatorial election, 1998}} Lingle would once again attempt an upset victory, this time in pursuit of the governor's office in 1998. Barred from seeking a third term as mayor of Maui, Lingle was nominated by the Hawai{{okina}}i Republican Party to run against incumbent Governor [[Benjamin J. Cayetano]]. Republican party members believed that Lingle was the best shot at the office and that 1998 would probably be the only chance the party would have of ever winning. Lingle capitalized on the anger of Hawai{{okina}}i residents over the stagnant economy and their dissatisfaction with the strategies employed by the Democrats in attempt to solve the problem. Cayetano trailed in the media polls heading into the November election but on the evening of the election, Cayetano and Lingle were separated by a single percentage point forcing a recount. Lingle was defeated in the closest election in Hawai{{okina}}i history.{{cite news |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/150/sesq5lingle |title=Linda Lingle |newspaper=The Honolulu Advertiser |first=Mike |last=Gordon |date=July 2, 2006 |accessdate=January 10, 2012 |quote=Lingle lost by the slimmest margin in Hawai'i history – 1.3 percent – prompting a recount that confirmed the results.}} The state Democratic Party was accused of launching a [[whisper campaign]] alleging that Lingle was a lesbian, and that she would abolish Christmas as a state holiday.{{cite web|url=http://starbulletin.com/1999/03/02/editorial/editorials.html |title=Lingle smear charge shouldn’t be dismissed |publisher=Honolulu Star-Bulletin Editorials |date=March 2, 1999 |accessdate=November 12, 2011}} Previously, Governor Cayetano had given state workers all of Christmas Eve day off, and other local government leaders followed suit – except then-Maui County Mayor Lingle, who said it would be too costly. ==State party chair== [[Image:Linda Lingle navy 2.jpg|thumb|250px|Linda Lingle smashes a bottle of champagne against the sail of the {{USS|Hawaii|SSN-776}} during the ship's christening ceremony.]] After being defeated, Lingle was elected chair of the Hawai{{okina}}i [[U.S. Republican Party|Republican Party]]. She served from 1999 to 2002. During her tenure as party chair, Lingle overhauled party policies and gave the party a lift she believed was needed to make the party competitive in a historically [[U.S. Democratic Party|Democratic Party]]-dominated state. Internal reforms proved successful and Lingle succeeded in electing more Republicans to seats in both houses of the Hawai{{okina}}i State Legislature. At the peak of Republican success, the party held 19 of the 51 seats in the state House of Representatives. Party membership grew as younger people joined. Republicans gained a more youthful appearance and had reinvented itself informally as the new GOP Hawai{{okina}}i. Lingle is a member of [[The Wish List (political organization)|The Wish List]], America's largest fundraising and campaign [[political action committee]] for Pro-choice Republican Women and The Republican Majority for Choice. ==Governor of Hawaii== ===2002 gubernatorial campaign=== {{Main|Hawaii gubernatorial election, 2002}} Barred from seeking a third term, Cayetano announced his retirement from political service in 2002. Having become even more popular among Hawaii residents, Lingle was nominated as the Republican candidate for the office of Governor of Hawaii. Her campaign was substantially aided when the popular favorite, Democratic Mayor of the City and County of Honolulu [[Jeremy Harris (politician)|Jeremy Harris]] withdrew after allegations of campaign finance irregularities. Hawaii Democrats then nominated incumbent Lieutenant Governor [[Mazie Hirono]]; it was one of the few gubernatorial races in which both major candidates were women. Lingle ran on her "Agenda for New Beginnings," a campaign platform developed to promote Republican leadership and highlight their criticisms of the previous 40 years of Democratic administration of the state. It also cited differences between Lingle's message and the previous, more conservative platforms which Hawaii Republicans had advocated. Focusing less on her mayoral accomplishments and more on the message of reform, Lingle won the election alongside former state judge [[Duke Aiona]], who became Lingle's lieutenant governor. Lingle was the first state Governor-elect not to be inaugurated at the Coronation Pavilion on the grounds of [[Iolani Palace]]. She was inaugurated in the rotunda of the [[Hawaii State Capitol]]. She took the [[oath of office]] upon a [[Tanakh]]. ===First term=== Lingle signed into law the [[Three-strikes law|Three Strikes Law]] and [[Sex offender registries in the United States|Sex Offender Registry Website Law]].{{cite web|url=http://republicanleague.org/2010/05/ |title=A Tale of Two Women |date=May 2010 |first=Mark |last=Herrick |publisher=California Republican League |accessdate=January 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728172247/http://republicanleague.org/2010/05/ |archivedate=July 28, 2011 }} She vetoed a bill that would have required all hospitals in Hawaii to provide [[emergency contraception]] to rape victims,{{cite news|url=http://www.msmagazine.com/news/uswirestory.asp?id=7904 |title=Hawaii Governor Vetoes EC Bill; State Lawmakers Consider Override |accessdate=September 2, 2012 |date=July 3, 2003}} concerned that Catholic hospitals would challenge it.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-82846067.html |title=Drive for Rape-Victim Contraception Slows |agency=Associated Press |first=David |last=Crary |date=September 27, 2003 |accessdate=September 2, 2012 |subscription=yes}} In May 2004 Lingle led a delegation to [[Israel]], paid for by the [[Israeli Government]].{{cite news |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2004/May/11/ln/ln29a.html |title=Lingle, Hawai'i delegation to visit Israel next week |first=B.J. |last=Reyes |newspaper=The Honolulu Advertiser |agency=Associated Press |date=May 11, 2004 |accessdate=January 10, 2012 |quote=The Israeli government is paying all expenses for Lingle, Aiona, the governor's communications adviser Lenny Klompus, and half the expenses for Kunimoto and Koller.}}{{cite news |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2004/May/25/ln/ln46a.html |title=Lingle backs Bush on Iraq, Israel policies |last=Dunford |first=Bruce |newspaper=The Honolulu Advertiser |agency=Associated Press |date=May 25, 2004 |accessdate=January 10, 2012 |quote=Lingle returned to her office yesterday after a weeklong trip – along with a 27-member delegation – to Israel, where she met with top leaders and discussed agricultural cooperation.}} She enjoyed high approval ratings, usually around 70 percent.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/ref/washington/raceprofile_HAWAIIGOV.html |title=The Hawaii Governor’s Race |first=Jesse |last=McKinley |newspaper=The New York Times |quote=Ms. Lingle – who has regularly enjoyed approval ratings over 70 percent – is one of the least nervous Republicans around. |accessdate=January 10, 2012 |date=August 23, 2006}} Lingle spent much of 2004 campaigning for Republican candidates, both in the Presidential election and the Hawaii state legislature. She supported President [[George W. Bush]]'s Iraq policies,{{cite news |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2004/May/25/ln/ln46a.html |title=Lingle backs Bush on Iraq, Israel policies |last=Dunford |first=Bruce |newspaper=The Honolulu Advertiser |agency=Associated Press |date=May 25, 2004 |accessdate=September 2, 2012 |quote=Republican Gov. Linda Lingle expressed support yesterday for President Bush's Iraq policies, which she believes protect the security interests of the United States and keep the fight against terrorism there.}} and campaigned for Bush in the [[contiguous United States]]. When some polling late in the election showed Bush tied or narrowly leading Democrat [[John Kerry]], Lingle attempted to help Republicans carry her state for the first time since 1984. Vice President [[Dick Cheney]] also campaigned in the state. The state legislature had a Democratic supermajority and she wanted to have enough members to block them from overriding her vetoes. Ultimately, not only did Kerry win the state, but Republicans lost five seats in the state legislature, reducing their presence to near single-digits and causing the Democrats to consider Lingle more vulnerable than they initially expected. In spite of their new confidence, Lingle was re-elected after her 2006 re-election campaign. In education, she attempted to divide the State Board of Education into seven local school boards, but failed. One of the more controversial issues Lingle has championed is the practice of sending prisoners to the mainland, as opposed to building a new prison in Hawaii.{{cite web|last=Borreca |first=Richard |url=http://starbulletin.com/2006/07/14/news/story01.html |title=Lingle ends push for new prisons |publisher=Honolulu Star-Bulletin |date=July 14, 2006 |accessdate=November 12, 2011}} ===2006 gubernatorial election=== {{Main|Hawaii gubernatorial election, 2006}} [[File:Linda Lingle navy 1-cropped.jpg|thumb|250px|Linda Lingle in December 2006]] In 2006, Lingle announced her candidacy for re-election as Governor of Hawai{{okina}}i. In the Democratic Party, many people were speculated to run, but many of them declined, including State Senator [[Colleen Hanabusa]], then Senate President [[Robert Bunda|Bobby Bunda]], former Congressman [[Ed Case]] (who ran for U.S. Senate), U.S. Congressman [[Neil Abercrombie]], and [[Hawaii County, Hawaii|Hawaii County]] Mayor [[Harry Kim (politician)|Harry Kim]]. Despite the difficulty of finding an opponent for Lingle, former State Senator [[Randy Iwase]] decided to run for Governor. In the primary election he easily defeated Waianae Harbormaster [[William Aila Jr.]], and ended up with former Big Island State Senator [[Malama Solomon]] as his running mate. Over the course of the campaign, Iwase was considered an underdog who had only spent $340,000, compared to Lingle's $6 million; in his ads, he attacked Lingle over her relationship with President Bush. Governor Lingle won by the largest margin in state history, 63 percent to 35 percent. ===Second term=== In August 2007, the Hawaii Supreme Court invalidated a Lingle appointee's exemption of the [[Hawaii Superferry]] from having to undertake an environmental assessment before operating in Hawaii waters. The Superferry was an $80 million high-speed ferry. Despite the Court's ruling, the ferry sailed to Kauai without an environmental assessment. It was met by protesters on surfboards who turned the ferry back to Oahu. Lingle summoned a massive police and [[Coast Guard]] response. She told Kauai protesters that they would be charged under Hawaii's anti-terrorism laws if they continued to interfere with the Superferry's operation.{{cite news |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/surfers-vs-superferry |title=Surfers vs. the Superferry |magazine=The Nation |date=March 16, 2009 |first1=Jerry |last1=Manders |first2=Koohan |last2=Paik |quote=Her purpose was to instruct people that if they repeated their protests, they would be charged under new anti-terrorism laws that carry prison terms up to five years and/or a $10,000 fine. |accessdate=January 10, 2012}} Lingle sought a legislative exemption from environmental law on behalf of the Superferry (known as Act Two). Several Maui groups, including the [[Sierra Club]], Maui Tomorrow and the Kahului Harbor Coalition challenged the law as unconstitutional, citing a violation of [[separation of powers]], and favoritism towards a single company. The ferry suspended all Hawaii service in March 2009, days after the Hawaii Supreme Court struck down Act Two as unconstitutional.{{cite news |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/hawaii-court-backs-protestors-vs-superferry |title=Hawaii Court Backs Protestors vs. Superferry |magazine=The Nation |date=April 6, 2009 |first1=Jerry |last1=Manders |first2=Koohan |last2=Paik |accessdate=July 7, 2012}} ;2008 Republican Convention As she had four years before, Lingle campaigned for the Republican ticket, describing herself as "of the same breed as McCain and Palin."{{cite news|url=http://forward.com/articles/14146/hawaii-s-gop-governor-stands-out-/#ixzz25MqsNe94|accessdate=7 September 2012|title=Hawaii’s GOP Governor Stands Out|newspaper=Jewish Daily Forward|date=September 4, 2008|first=Brett|last=Lieberman}} She received national exposure when she delivered a primetime address on the third night of the [[2008 Republican National Convention]] praising [[John McCain]]'s choice of [[Governor of Alaska|Alaska Governor]] [[Sarah Palin]] as his vice-presidential running-mate.Honolulu Advertiser. [http://www.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/20080904/NEWS05/809040362/Lingle-lauds-truly-authentic-Palin Lingle lauds 'truly authentic' Palin]. Sept. 4, 2008. Lingle and Palin, both Republican [[List of female state governors in the United States|women governors]] of non-[[Contiguous United States|contiguous states]], are friends who grew acquainted through the [[Republican Governors Association]]. Lingle's speech filled the role of the traditional address formally nominating the vice-presidential candidate, though Palin was not officially nominated until the next night. ;Health care policies targeting legal immigrants and Compact of Free Association residents In July 2009, the Lingle Administration ended the Hawai{{okina}}i Immigrant Health Initiative, a state program providing medical coverage for legal immigrants present in the United States for fewer than five years. This move included the elimination of all residents present in Hawai{{okina}}i under the [[Compact of Free Association]] from QUEST, the state’s Medicaid coverage plan that assists the low income population in Hawai{{okina}}i with their health care needs. Noting that such a policy likely constituted unlawful discrimination in violation of the Equal Protection Clause, federal district court judge [[John Michael Seabright]] issued a preliminary injunction against the implementation of the substituted health care plan.{{cite court |litigants=Korab v. Koller |vol=2010 |reporter=WL |opinion=4688824 |court=D. Haw |date=Dec. 10, 2010 |url=http://www.lejhawaii.org/medicalaccess/pleadings/Korab43.pdf |quote=Defendants fail to show any particular State interest that is advanced by their decision to exclude COFA residents from the Old Programs. . . . [W]hile the court recognizes that BHH was created in response to the State's budget crisis, when applying strict scrutiny, the 'justification of limiting expenses is particularly inappropriate and unreasonable when the discriminated class consists of aliens'}}; see also [http://www.yokwe.net/index.php?module=News&func=display&sid=2706 Judge Dismisses Hawaii’s Request for Dismissal of Suit against Basic Health Hawaii]("Micronesian community representatives reported that elimination of medical benefits has impacted many, including 27 who have died since Sept. 1, 2009") Subsequent Governor [[Neil Abercrombie]] indicated that he may continue the State's appeal of the injunction to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lejhawaii.org/medicalaccess/pleadings/10-483_notice_appeal_pi.pdf|title=Korab v. Koller, Civ. No. 10-c00483-JMS-KSC (Jan. 10, 2011)|publisher=The Hawai‘i Appleseed Center for Law and Economic Justice}} ;School furlough sit-in On April 13, 2010, two student protesters who were occupying her office were arrested and criminal trespassing citations were issued to eight others.{{cite web|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/global/story.asp?s=12307143 |title=Protestors arrested at Governor Lingle's office |publisher=Hawaii News Now |date=April 14, 2010 |accessdate=November 12, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/20100413/BREAKING01/100413055/Two+arrested++8+others+cited+on+day+7+of+furlough+sit-in |title=2 Hawaii protesters arrested, 8 others ticketed for school furlough sit-in |publisher=Honolulu Star Advertiser |date=April 13, 2010 |accessdate=November 12, 2011}} The demonstrators were part of a sit-in to protest a school furlough policy implemented due to budget shortages.The Associated Press. [https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2010/04/10/us/AP-US-Hawaii-School-Year.html Parents Issued Citations at Hawaii Furlough Sit-In]. April 10, 2010. The following day, April 14, two more protesters were arrested and citations were issued to five other protesters. ;Civil union veto Lingle on July 6, 2010 vetoed [[Hawaii House Bill 444]], which would have allowed for [[civil union]]s [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Hawaii#Civil unions|for couples in Hawaii]], arguing the issue should be decided by referendum.{{cite news|title=Hawaii governor vetoes same-sex civil unions bill|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=July 6, 2010|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2010-07-06-hawaii-civil-unions-veto_N.htm|accessdate=February 6, 2012}} The bill had passed the State House with three votes less than the two-thirds vote threshold necessary to override the veto, although the bill met that threshold in the State Senate.{{cite news| last=Reyes | first=B.J. | title=Veto override session dead | date=July 7, 2012 | newspaper=Honolulu Star-Advertiser | url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/news/20100703_veto_override_session_dead.html | accessdate=2012-09-16}} ==2012 U.S. Senate election== {{Main|United States Senate election in Hawaii, 2012}} In October 2011, Lingle said on [[KSSK-FM|KSSK]] radio show that she would run for the open seat vacated by retiring U.S. Senator [[Daniel Akaka]] (D-HI). She won the Republican primary election on August 11, 2012 against nominal opposition and faced Hirono in the general election – a repeat of the 2002 gubernatorial race.{{cite web |url=http://hawaii.gov/elections/results/2012/primary/elections/results/2012/primary/files/histatewide.pdf |title=Primary Election 2012 – State of Hawaii – Final Summary Report |publisher=State of Hawaii, Office of Elections |date=August 12, 2012 |accessdate=August 13, 2012}} Lingle was the first reasonably well-funded Republican to run for the Senate in Hawaii since [[Pat Saiki]] ran in the 1990 special election against Akaka, and the strongest Republican candidate for a full term in the Senate from the state in memory. Although a poll in the summer of 2012 showed the race as close as five points,{{cite news |url=http://www.civilbeat.com/articles/2012/06/12/16045-civil-beat-poll-case-hirono-tied-in-hawaii-us-senate-race/#2 |title=Civil Beat Poll – Case, Hirono Tied In Hawaii U.S. Senate Race |newspaper=Civil Beat |publisher=Peer News |date=June 12, 2012 |first=Michael |last=Levine |accessdate=December 25, 2012 |quote=Hirono holds an early 49 percent to 44 percent lead over Lingle }} ultimately Hirono defeated Lingle with 63 percent of the vote to Lingle's 37 percent. ==After 2012== After her failed Senate bid, Lingle taught a public policy seminar at [[California State University, Northridge]], from which she had graduated in 1975. She also gave lectures and worked with the Governor's Council and Energy Security Council for the [[Bipartisan Policy Center]].{{cite news |title=Illinois governor adds Lingle to staff |newspaper=Honolulu Star-Advertiser |date=January 23, 2015 |first=Timothy |last=Hurley |pages=A19, A23}} In January 2015, Lingle was appointed as a senior adviser to Illinois Governor [[Bruce Rauner]]. She was to join a trio of outsiders in May/June 2015 to work on problems such as the state's retirement system and low credit ratings. Lingle left the chief operating officer position in July 2016.{{cite news |url=http://www.sj-r.com/news/20160701/former-hawaii-gov-lingle-leaves-rauner-administration-new-epa-head-also-named |title=Former Hawaii Gov. Lingle leaves Rauner administration; new EPA head also named |newspaper=The State Journal-Register |publisher=Gatehouse Media |date=July 1, 2016 |access-date=July 20, 2016 }}{{cite news |url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/news/former-hawaii-gov-linda-lingle-says-aloha-rauner-administration/ |title=Ex-Hawaii Gov. Linda Lingle says aloha to Rauner administration |date=July 1, 2016 |access-date=July 20, 2016 |newspaper=Chicago Sun-Times }}{{cite press release |url=https://www.iml.org/file.cfm?key=9986 |title=Governor Announces Appointments, Staff Changes |publisher=Office of the Governor |date=July 1, 2016 |access-date=July 20, 2016 |agency=Illinois Municipal League |page=2 |quote=Deputy Governor Trey Childress will add to his duties and take on the additional role of Chief Operating Officer. }} Weeks later, she delivered an opening-day speech at the [[2016 Republican National Convention]] about Jewish support for the party and its presidential nominee.{{cite news |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/news/2016/07/19/former-hawaii-governors-speech-at-the-rnc-forces.html |newspaper=Pacific Business News |title=Former Hawaii governor's speech at the RNC forces live chat shutdown |date=July 19, 2016 |first=Janis L. |last=Magin |access-date=September 19, 2018 }} In January 2017, Lingle announced at a Republican gathering that she planned to move back to Hawaii in April 2017.{{cite news |url=https://www.pressreader.com/usa/honolulu-star-advertiser/20170105/281530815700294 |newspaper=Honolulu Star-Advertiser |via=PressReader |date=January 5, 2017 |access-date=December 12, 2017 |first=Sophie |last=Cooke |title=Former Gov. Linda Lingle speaks at gala celebrating Trump }} In May 2017, she was one of four former governors brought together by [[Harvard University]] to discuss issues related to the nation's [[opioid epidemic|opioid crisis]].{{cite news |url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/2017/05/04/breaking-news/linda-lingle-to-join-panel-of-ex-governors-at-harvard/ |title=Linda Lingle to join panel of ex-governors at Harvard |date=May 4, 2017 |access-date=December 12, 2017 |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=Honolulu Star-Advertiser }} Lingle became a member of [[Hawaii Pacific University]]'s board of trustees in June 2017.{{cite web |url=https://www.hpu.edu/about-us/news-and-events/news/2017/06/board-of-trustees-appointment.html |title=Hawaiʻi Pacific University Board of Trustees Announces Chairman of the Board and New Board Member |publisher=Hawaii Pacific University |date=June 7, 2017 |access-date=September 20, 2018 }} ==Personal life== Lingle was married and divorced twice. She married her first husband, Charles Lingle, while in college, in 1972. Upon leaving California for Hawaii, she divorced him in 1975 but kept the Lingle name. During her term as mayor of Maui County, Lingle divorced her second husband, Maui attorney William Crockett, to whom she was married from 1986 to 1997. Lingle is currently single and does not have any children. Her uncle founded the Cutter [[Ford]] car dealerships in [[Hawaii|Hawai{{okina}}i]].{{cite web|last=Borreca |first=Richard |url=http://starbulletin.com/98/07/13/news/story2.html |title=In Their Words: Linda Lingle |publisher=Honolulu Star-Bulletin |date=July 13, 1998 |accessdate=November 12, 2011}} Lingle is active in the [[Republican Jewish Coalition]], serving as a speaker at events and otherwise using her role as the only Jewish Republican US governor. President [[George W. Bush]] appointed her to serve on the Honorary Delegation to accompany him to [[Jerusalem]] for the celebration of the 60th anniversary of the [[State of Israel]] in May 2008.{{cite web|last=Lake |first=Eli |url=http://www.nysun.com/foreign/bush-visit-may-boost-olmert/76303/ |title=Bush Visit May Boost Olmert |work=The New York Sun |date=May 13, 2008 |accessdate=November 12, 2011}} ==Electoral history== {{Election box begin |title=[[Hawaii gubernatorial election, 1998|Hawaii Gubernatorial Election 1998]]}} {{Election box candidate with party link | |party = Democratic Party (US) |candidate = [[Ben Cayetano]] (incumbent) |votes = 204,206 |percentage = 50 |change = }} {{Election box candidate with party link | |party = Republican Party (US) |candidate = Linda Lingle |votes = 198,952 |percentage = 49 |change = }} {{Election box candidate with party link | |party = Libertarian Party (US) |candidate = [[Molokai Advertiser-News|George Peabody]] |votes = 4,398 |percentage = 1 |change = }} {{Election box end}} {{Election box begin |title=[[Hawaii gubernatorial election, 2002|Hawaii Gubernatorial Election 2002]]}} {{Election box candidate with party link | |party = Republican Party (US) |candidate = Linda Lingle |votes = 194,338 |percentage = 52 |change = }} {{Election box candidate with party link | |party = Democratic Party (US) |candidate = [[Mazie Hirono]] |votes = 177,186 |percentage = 47 |change = }} {{Election box end}} {{Election box begin |title=[[Hawaii gubernatorial election, 2006|Hawaii Gubernatorial Election 2006]]}} {{Election box candidate with party link | (Lingle is featured on page 6) ''[[Maui No Ka 'Oi Magazine]]'' Vol. 12 No. 3 (May 2008). {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Hannibal Tavares]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Mayor of Maui]]|years=1991–1999}} {{s-aft|after=[[James Apana|Kimo Apana]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Ben Cayetano]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Governor of Hawaii]]|years=2002–2010}} {{s-aft|after=[[Neil Abercrombie]]}} |- {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Pat Saiki]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nominee for [[Governor of Hawaii]]|years=[[Hawaii gubernatorial election, 1998|1998]], [[Hawaii gubernatorial election, 2002|2002]], [[Hawaii gubernatorial election, 2006|2006]]}} {{s-aft|after=[[Duke Aiona]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Cynthia Thielen]]}} {{s-ttl|title={{nowrap|[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nominee for [[United States Senator|U.S. Senator]] from [[Hawaii]]}}

page.title: List of Australian of the Year Award recipients

revision.text:
{{pp-semi|small=yes}} The '''Australian of the Year Award''' is given annually on [[Australia Day]]. The announcement of the award has become a major public event in Australia, and is televised nationwide. The award "offers an insight into Australian identity, reflecting the nation's evolving relationship with world, the role of sport in Australian culture, the impact of multiculturalism, and the special status of Australia's Indigenous people".http://www.australianoftheyear.org.au/the-awards/awards-history/ The award is unique in that it is sponsored by a national government and commands broad public support. The following is a list of the recipients of the [[Australian of the Year]] award.[http://www.australianoftheyear.org.au/honour-roll/ Australian of the Year - Honour Roll]{{cite book | author=[[Wendy Lewis|Lewis, Wendy]] | title=Australians of the Year | publisher=Pier 9 Press | year=2010 | isbn=978-1-74196-809-5 }} {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Year of
award ! Name ! Post
nominals ! Born ! Died ! i.e. Mandawuy Yunupingu was named Australian of the Year for 1992 in 1993 and Ian Kiernan was named Australian of the Year for 1994 in 1994'' |- | 1994 | {{sortname|Ian|Kiernan}} | {{post-nominals|country=AUS|sep=,|OAM}} | 1940 | | Environmentalist; This is a '''list of people from Monaco'''.
*[[Romeo Acquarone]] (1895–1980), tennis player *[[Louis Chiron]] (1899-1979), [[Formula One]] racing driver *[[Georges Vigarello]] (born 1941), historian and sociologist *[[Olivier Beretta]] (born 1969), Formula One racing driver *[[Laetitia Mikail]] (born 1980s), lawyer and event planner *[[Charles Leclerc (racing driver)|Charles Leclerc]] (born 1997), Formula One racing driver
